PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Migraine is a disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of severe headache often associated with other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, and sometimes preceded by aura.  It is a common disorder affecting around 15% of women and 6% of men over a one year period.  The economic costs are significant with 1.3 days per month lost to absenteeism, and the personal costs can be high with a reduced quality of life.  In addition, people with migraine are more likely to have comorbid conditions such as depression and anxiety.  There are many possible triggers for migraine including: lack of sleep, stress, exercise, certain foods, hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle, and bright or flashing lights.  While there is no cure for migraine, treatments are available to help abort an attack or reduce the number of attacks.  Abortive treatments include: pain relief medication, triptans, ergotamine, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  Prophylactic treatments include: beta blockers, antidepressants, anticonvulsants, Botox injections, and Botox injections.  The goal of treatment is to reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.  Treatment is individualized based on patient-specific factors such as: age, comorbid medical conditions, medication history, and frequency and severity of attacks.  In general, the first line of treatment is usually an abortive medication.  If the frequency of attacks is high (more than two per month), a prophylactic medication is added to the treatment regimen.  A headache diary is recommended to help the patient track their headache frequency, severity, and possible triggers.  It is also recommended that the patient try to identify triggers and eliminate them if possible. Some of these medications, such as propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, and sodium valproate, are also used to prevent migraines. PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Summary: The pharmacologic treatment of migraine has been the subject of intense research for the past 25 years. In addition to the development of the triptans, a new class of antimigraine drugs, there have been many studies of the use of beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, anticonvulsants, and serotonin 5-HT2 receptor antagonists in the treatment of migraine. This has led to the establishment of first-line agents for the treatment of migraine. 2. Objective: To review the evidence supporting the use of these first-line agents for the treatment of migraine. 3. Data Sources: A MEDLINE search was conducted using the terms migraine, treatment, and trials. The Cochrane Collaboration was also consulted. 4. Study Selection: All English-language, randomized, controlled trials that compared active treatment with placebo in the treatment of migraine were selected. Studies that involved only prophylaxis were excluded. 5. Data Extraction: Data were extracted on study design, patient population, methods of assessing efficacy, and results. 6. Conclusion: The data from randomized controlled trials show that when a patient with migraine presents in the office, the first-line treatments are prochlorperazine, narcotic + prochlorperazine, ergotamine, and sumatriptan. When a patient with migraine calls for help, the first-line treatment is sumatriptan.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 2012: First-line therapies for the acute treatment of migraine are NSAIDs and triptans. Both are considered effective for all types of migraine. However, triptans are considered to be most effective in patients with migraine associated with nausea and vomiting. Triptans are also considered to be most effective in patients with migraine associated with photophobia and phonophobia. NSAIDs are considered to be most effective in patients with migraine without aura.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism--the way the body uses energy--and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down.  Hypothyroidism is often called underactive thyroid. Hypothyroidism can be caused by problems in the thyroid gland or by problems in the pituitary gland, the part of the brain that makes thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). TSH tells the thyroid gland how much thyroid hormone to make.  Most people with hypothyroidism have the condition because they have an underactive thyroid gland. This is called primary hypothyroidism. Primary hypothyroidism is usually the result of an autoimmune disorder. Autoimmune disorders cause the body to make antibodies that attack the thyroid gland. These antibodies cause the thyroid gland to make too little thyroid hormone.  Other causes of primary hypothyroidism include thyroid gland surgery, radiation treatment of the thyroid gland, and certain medicines that can damage the thyroid gland.  Some people have hypothyroidism because their pituitary gland does not make enough TSH. This is called secondary hypothyroidism. Causes include tumors of the pituitary gland and brain, and damage to the pituitary gland from radiation treatment or trauma.  The most common cause of hypothyroidism is an autoimmune disorder called Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is more common in women and people with a family history of thyroid disease. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is also called chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.  Other causes of hypothyroidism include radiation treatment of the thyroid gland, and certain medicines that can damage the thyroid gland.

Hypothyroidism can also be caused by radiation treatment of the thyroid, certain medicines, and severe illness. 7. Symptoms of hypothyroidism in children may include the following: 8. In children, symptoms may include: - Changes in heart rate or rhythm - Depression - Difficulty concentrating - Dry skin - Fatigue - Forgetfulness - Weight gain 10. In teens, symptoms may include: - Early menstruation or late periods - Extreme sensitivity to cold - Hair loss - Weight gain 11. Hypothyroidism is diagnosed with a blood test that measures the level of thyroid hormone in the blood. 12. Treatment of hypothyroidism involves taking a thyroid hormone pill every day. 13. With treatment, children with hypothyroidism can lead normal lives.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Lewy body dementia is a type of dementia that involves a decrease in thinking and reasoning skills and changes in behavior. People with Lewy body dementia may experience depression, anxiety, and hallucinations (sights, sounds, smells, tastes, or touches that a person believes to be real but are not real). This type of dementia occurs when abnormal structures, called Lewy bodies, develop in the brain. The disease gets its name from these abnormal structures.  Lewy body dementia is one of the most common forms of dementia. It is often misdiagnosed as Alzheimer's disease or Parkinson's disease because the symptoms are similar.  Lewy body dementia is caused by abnormal protein structures, called Lewy bodies, developing in the brain. The disease occurs when these abnormal structures accumulate and die nerve cells in specific areas of the brain.  Lewy body dementia symptoms occur when these nerve cells die in the areas of the brain involved in thinking, reasoning, and movement.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Lewy body dementia is a type of dementia that involves abnormal structures in the brain called Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are composed of a protein called alpha-synuclein. In Lewy body dementia, the number of Lewy bodies in the brain increases, causing problems with thinking, movement and behavior. Lewy body dementia usually occurs sporadically in people with no family history of the disease. However, rare familial forms have been described. Symptoms of Lewy body dementia include: * Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness * Recurrent visual hallucinations, usually related to people or animals * Spontaneous motor features of parkinsonism (slowness of movement, stiffness, muscle rigidity, gait and posture disturbances), or features of other synucleinopathies (such as, multisystem atrophy or pure autonomic failure) * Sleep disturbances (e.g., REM sleep behavior disorder), often with excessive daytime sleepiness * Neuropsychiatric symptoms (delusions, depression, apathy, anxiety) * REM sleep behavior disorder is a condition in which the muscles are active during REM sleep. This results in jerky movements during dreams. People with this condition often act out their dreams, which can include kicking, punching, screaming or shouting. REM sleep behavior disorder is often associated with Lewy body dementia, but it can also occur without dementia. Diagnosis of Lewy body dementia requires a brain biopsy or postmortem examination to confirm the presence of Lewy bodies. Other conditions can cause similar symptoms, including Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. Lewy body dementia is often misdiagnosed as Alzheimer's disease because the symptoms are similar. Lewy body dementia is distinguished from Alzheimer's disease by the presence of visual hallucinations, spontaneous motor features of parkinsonism, and the absence of Alzheimer's disease pathology (i.e., beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles) on brain biopsy or autopsy. There is no cure for Lewy body

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 3-SCA3: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 is a rare, autosomal dominant disorder that causes progressive problems with movement. It is caused by a mutation in the ATXN3 gene. The symptoms of SCA3 usually begin in adulthood, but can begin at any age. Symptoms may include uncoordinated, jerky body movements (dysmetria), unsteady gait, muscle stiffness (dystonia), muscle weakness, and problems with speech or swallowing. People with SCA3 may also experience problems with thinking and memory (cognitive impairment), sleep disorders, and depression.

People with this condition may also have problems with thinking and memory. 3. There is no cure for SCA3, but medicines and lifestyle changes may help relieve some symptoms. 4. People with the disease have a 50% chance of passing it on to each of their children.

1. In congenital heart disease (CHD), the heart is malformed from birth. 2. CHD is the most common of all birth defects, affecting about 1 of every 100 newborns. 3. It is more common in premature babies and in babies whose mothers had a viral infection during pregnancy. 4. CHD can be very mild or so severe that it causes almost immediate death after birth. 5. Treatment of mild cases may involve only careful monitoring. 6. Treatment of severe cases may involve surgery, sometimes as early as the first day of life.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. A congenital heart defect is a problem with the structure of the heart that is present at birth. 2. Many congenital heart defects don't need treatment, but some do. 3. Some congenital heart defects are minor. They may never cause problems and may not need treatment. Other congenital heart defects are serious and can be life-threatening. 4. The heart is a complex organ with several roles, including pumping blood throughout the body. The heart has 4 chambers and 4 valves. 5. A congenital heart defect is a problem that is present at birth. It is a problem with the structure of the heart. 6. Blood goes through a pathway that starts in the right atrium. It then goes through a valve (the tricuspid valve) into the right ventricle. From there, it goes through another valve (the pulmonary valve) into the pulmonary artery, which takes the blood to the lungs. 7. In the lungs, the blood gets oxygenated. After the lungs, the oxygenated blood goes through a valve (the mitral valve) into the left atrium. It then goes through a valve (the aortic valve) into the aorta, which carries the blood throughout the body. 8. A congenital heart defect is a problem with the structure of the heart. It can affect any part of the pathway, including the heart chambers or the valves. 9. Some congenital heart defects are minor. They may never cause problems and may not need treatment. Other congenital heart defects are serious and can be life-threatening. 10. An atrial septal defect (ASD) is a problem with the septum (the wall) between the left and right atria. It is one of the most common congenital heart defects. 11. A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a problem with the septum (the wall) between the left and right ventricles. It is the most common congenital heart defect. 12. An atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) is a problem with the septum (the wall) between the atria and the ventricles.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Congenital heart disease is the most common of all birth defects. 2. About 40% of children with congenital heart defects have other birth defects. 3. Some congenital heart defects, such as atrial septal defects (ASDs), may not be diagnosed until later in life. 4. Some congenital heart defects, such as patent foramen ovale (PFO), are common and may not require treatment. 5. With current surgical techniques, many infants and children with more complex congenital heart defects can be treated successfully.

This information will need to include the type of lung cancer, the age at which they developed lung cancer, and whether there was any family history of lung cancer.  With this information, a geneticist can determine if there is a pattern of lung cancer that suggests an inherited form of lung cancer.  The information can also be put into a computer program that can estimate the likelihood that your husband's family has an inherited form of lung cancer.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Fibromyalgia is a disorder that causes muscle pain and fatigue. People with fibromyalgia have "tender points" on the body. Tender points are specific places on the neck, shoulders, back, hips, arms, and legs. These points hurt when pressure is put on them.  People with fibromyalgia may also have other symptoms, such as:  - Trouble sleeping  - Morning stiffness  - Headaches  - Painful menstrual periods  - Tingling or numbness in hands and feet  - Problems with thinking and memory (sometimes called "fibro fog")  - Depression or anxiety  - Problems with moving around  - Muscle twitches  - Lack of energy    A diagnosis of fibromyalgia is done by looking for the number of tender points. People with fibromyalgia may also have other health problems. These can include:  - Osteoarthritis  - Rheumatoid arthritis  - Irritable bowel syndrome  - Restless legs syndrome  - Temporomandibular joint disorder (TMJ)  - Chronic fatigue syndrome    No one knows what causes fibromyalgia. Anyone can get it, but it is most common in middle-aged women. People with rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases are particularly likely to develop fibromyalgia.

In some cases, the condition is caused by an inherited genetic mutation. In other cases, it may be triggered by another condition, such as chronic kidney disease or diabetes. 3. The symptoms of distal renal tubular acidosis can vary from person to person. Some people have no symptoms. Others may have symptoms such as weakness, fatigue, or loss of appetite. 4. The diagnosis is based on a blood test that measures the level of acid in the blood. Other tests may be done to determine the cause of the condition. 5. Treatment may include taking potassium citrate or sodium bicarbonate. In severe cases, dialysis may be needed. 6. To find more information and support, you may try searching the following links: The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) at https://www.niddk.nih.gov/ The Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD) at https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/ The National Library of Medicine's Gene and Disease databases at https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/geneanddisease.html
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Distal renal tubular acidosis is a disease that occurs when the kidneys do not properly remove acids from the blood into the urine. As a result, too much acid remains in the blood (called acidosis). 2. The most common form of distal renal tubular acidosis is called type 1, or A. This condition occurs when the kidneys do not properly secrete hydrogen ions (H+) into the urine. 3. A type 2 form of distal renal tubular acidosis occurs when the kidneys do not properly reabsorb bicarbonate (HCO3-) from the urine. 4. A third form of distal renal tubular acidosis (type 3) occurs when the kidneys do not properly respond to the hormone aldosterone.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a long term (chronic) disease characterized by the gradual loss of kidney function. It is a common condition, affecting 1 in 9 adults. The most common causes of CKD are diabetes, high blood pressure, and glomerulonephritis (a group of diseases that cause inflammation of the filtering units in the kidneys). 2. The kidneys are responsible for filtering wastes and extra fluid from your blood. When the kidneys are damaged, they are not able to remove the wastes and fluid, which can build up in your blood and cause problems. 3. As the kidneys stop working, waste builds up in the body causing complications such as anemia (low red blood cell count), bone disease, poor appetite, nausea and vomiting, confusion, and swelling. 4. CKD can lead to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), also known as kidney failure. ESRD occurs when the kidneys no longer work to remove wastes and fluid from your blood. Without treatment, people with ESRD die. 5. Treatment for CKD includes medicines, dietary changes, and dialysis or kidney transplantation.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Use of insecticides: Insecticides are chemicals that kill insects. They can be contact poisons, stomach poisons, fumigants, and space sprays. Contact poisons are applied directly to the bodies of insects and are effective only on those insects that come in contact with the poison. Stomach poisons are taken into the insect's body through the mouth and kill the insect after a period of feeding. Fumigants are gases or vapors that are introduced into buildings or other enclosed areas to kill insects. They are especially effective against moths and beetles. Space sprays are general insecticides that are applied as a mist or fog to kill insects by contact and by stomach poisoning. 2. Traps: Traps are devices that use color, chemicals, and/or heat to lure insects. Once the insects are in the trap, they are killed by dehydration or by exposure to fumes. Traps are effective only in the immediate area around the trap. 3. Biological controls: Biological controls involve the use of natural enemies of insects to kill pests. Biological controls include the use of predators and parasites that feed on insect pests. Biological controls also include the use of insect-eating bacteria, viruses, and fungi. 4. Destruction of breeding areas: If the breeding areas for insects can be destroyed, the insect population can be greatly reduced. 5. Protective measures: Protective measures include the use of pesticides and repellents. Pesticides are chemicals that are used to kill insects. Repellents are substances that prevent insects from feeding on plants or animals. 6. Cultural controls: Cultural controls include the use of natural and synthetic methods to reduce the number of insects. Examples of cultural controls include flooding areas to prevent mosquitoes from breeding and the use of crops that are resistant to insect feeding. 7. Cultural control: Cultural control is the use of methods to manage the growth and distribution of insects. Examples of cultural control include flooding areas to prevent mosquitoes from breeding and the use of crops that are resistant to insect feeding.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) is a rare, inherited disorder that causes progressive destruction of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. The most common form of TSD is caused by the absence of a vital enzyme called hexosaminidase A (HEXA). Without this enzyme, a fatty substance, or lipid, called GM2 ganglioside accumulates abnormally in cells, especially in the nerve cells of the brain. This accumulation causes progressive damage to the cells and leads to the symptoms of TSD. TSD is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that both copies of the gene must be altered for symptoms to develop. In most cases, both parents of a child with an autosomal recessive condition are unaffected carriers of the altered gene, and have one copy of the altered gene in their genetic makeup. In some cases, one parent may have the condition while the other parent is an unaffected carrier of the altered gene. If both parents are carriers of the altered gene, there is a 25% chance with each pregnancy that their child will develop the condition. TSD is caused by a defective gene on chromosome 15. The term "Tay-Sachs" refers to the two researchers who first described the disease in 1881. 2. Tay-Sachs disease is not preventable at this time. 3. Tay-Sachs disease affects 1 in 300,000 people in the United States. The incidence is higher among the Ashkenazi Jewish population, in which 1 in 250 people are carriers. 4. The National Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases Association (NTSAD) is a non-profit organization that provides information and support for individuals and families affected by Tay-Sachs and other genetic diseases. NTSAD offers a wide variety of services, including patient registration, patient and family support, educational materials, research and professional programs, and referrals to genetic counseling and treatment centers. Specialized care can help individuals live as long as possible.

Hairy cell leukemia is a rare, slow-growing blood and bone marrow disease that occurs when the bone marrow does not make enough normal blood cells and there are too many abnormal B cells (lymphocytes) in the blood and bone marrow.2. PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Hairy cell leukemia is a rare form of cancer that affects B cells, a type of white blood cell (lymphocyte). It was first described in 1958, and the disease-causing agent was identified in 1990. The disease gets its name from the appearance of the cells under a microscope. Hairy cell leukemia affects B cells in the bone marrow, where red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are produced. It causes an accumulation of mature B cells that look abnormal and have "hairy" cytoplasmic projections.  The disease is characterized by splenomegaly (enlargement of the spleen), which results in abdominal pain or discomfort. Other symptoms include fever, weight loss, and weakness. Most patients are diagnosed after age 50, but the age range is wide. More men than women are diagnosed with hairy cell leukemia.  The disease is treated with chemotherapy and/or biological therapy. Chemotherapy uses drugs to kill cancer cells. Biological therapy uses substances made from living organisms to enhance the body's ability to fight cancer. Treatment with chemotherapy drugs and interferon results in a complete remission (no evidence of disease) in about 75 percent of patients. The disease may come back (relapse) in about half of patients, but it can be treated again. The average survival after diagnosis is about 10 years.

This can help to keep your blood sugar levels stable throughout the night.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Diabetes is a chronic disease that occurs when your body cannot effectively use the sugar (glucose) in your blood. 2. Glucose comes from the food you eat and is also made in your liver. Glucose is the main source of energy for your body's cells.3. Your blood carries the glucose to all of your body's cells, but the cells can only use glucose if it is available to them in the bloodstream. To get glucose into your bloodstream, your body produces a hormone called insulin. Insulin allows the glucose to leave the bloodstream and enter the cells.4. In people with diabetes, this does not happen. Either the body doesn't make enough insulin or the insulin that is made doesn't work as well as it should. 5. Glucose stays in the bloodstream instead of going into the cells, so the amount of glucose in the bloodstream increases.6. High blood sugar levels can damage the small blood vessels in the kidneys, heart, eyes, feet, and other parts of the body. This damage may lead to pain, organ failure, and other serious problems.7. There are two types of diabetes: type 1 and type 2.8. Type 1 diabetes, also called insulin-dependent diabetes, is usually diagnosed in children and young adults. In type 1 diabetes, the body does not produce insulin.9. In type 2 diabetes, also called non-insulin-dependent diabetes, the body usually produces insulin, but the insulin that is produced does not work as well as it should. Type 2 diabetes is the most common type of diabetes.10. Gestational diabetes is diabetes that occurs during pregnancy.11. If you have diabetes, your blood glucose, or blood sugar, levels are too high. Glucose comes from the food you eat and is also made in your liver. Glucose is the main source of energy for your body's cells.12. Your blood carries the glucose to all of your body's cells, but the cells can only use glucose if it is available to them in the blood

Glucose remains in the bloodstream, and excess glucose is stored in the liver and extra fat is stored in the body. 2. The urine bladder becomes heavier because of increased urine production due to increased glucose in the bloodstream. This excess glucose is being excreted in the urine.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. The brain, stomach, and urine bladder are organs that are very active metabolically and have a high rate of glucose utilization. The reason that these organs have such a high glucose utilization is that they have a very high rate of energy expenditure due to their activity. 2. The urine bladder gains more weight than other body parts because it is constantly being filled with urine, which stretches the bladder wall, thereby increasing its mass.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The pancreas in a diabetic patient does not produce insulin, or produces only a small amount of insulin. Insulin is needed to allow glucose to enter cells. Without insulin, glucose remains in the blood. High levels of glucose spill into the urine because the kidneys cannot reabsorb all the glucose. The extra glucose in the urine increases the volume of urine. As a result, the bladder has to work harder to pump urine out of the body. 2. The brain cannot use glucose without insulin. As a result, the brain must use alternative sources of energy, such as fats and proteins. This metabolism produces waste products that are normally excreted by the kidneys. Because the kidneys are busy reabsorbing glucose, they cannot adequately excrete the waste products, which may build up in the blood. These waste products may affect the function of the brain.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. High blood sugar levels stimulate the pancreas to produce more insulin, which is stored in the liver. When the liver releases glucose into the bloodstream, it also releases some into the poal system to be stored in the stomach and intestines. The intestines can absorb glucose directly from the intestinal lumen, but the stomach cannot. However, the stomach can absorb fructose and other sugars. 2. The urinary bladder is a diverticulum of the intestinal tract, and so it shares some of the same properties as the intestines. It can absorb glucose directly from the urinary lumen, and it can absorb fructose and other sugars. 3. The brain cannot absorb glucose directly from the cerebral lumen because it has no glucose transporter proteins on its surface. However, the brain contains a protein called GLUT, which is a glucose transporter protein that is similar to the ones found in the intestines and kidneys. The GLUT protein found in the brain is not able to absorb fructose and other sugars. 4. The extra weight in the urinary bladder comes from the absorption of glucose and fructose from the urinary lumen.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. The urinary bladder has a more intimate relationship with the regulation of blood sugar levels in diabetes patients than other body parts. 2. The urinary bladder is more prone to weight gain compared to other body parts.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The condition is known as Trimethylaminuria and not TMAU. 2. Trimethylaminuria is a rare inherited genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of the body. It is characterized by the presence of an offensive body odor that smells like rotten fish, rotting eggs, garbage, or urine. 3. The condition is caused due to a defect in the Flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 (FMO3) gene. 4. FMO3 gene mutation leads to the reduced activity of the enzyme which normally breaks down trimethylamine (TMA) in the body. 5. As a result, TMA accumulates in the body and is released through the urine and sweat causing the typical odor. 6. The condition is passed on in families (inherited) and is more common in people with a family history of the condition. 7. There is no cure for trimethylaminuria and the odor can persist throughout life. 8. Treatments that have been suggested for trimethylaminuria include:  - Dietary changes  - Bathing more frequently  - Wearing loose-fitting cotton clothing  - Avoiding foods that contain high amounts of trimethylamine (e.g., eggs, fish, dried beans, and peas)  - Taking antibiotics (for secondary bacterial infections)  - Taking activated charcoal tablets  - Taking chlorhexidine body washes  - Taking probiotics  - Taking vitamin B supplements 9. Gene therapy is still under research and has not been found effective in treating trimethylaminuria.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. What is trimethylaminuria (TMAU)? Trimethylaminuria (TMAU) is a condition characterised by an offensive body odour that smells like rotting fish, faeces or garbage. It is caused by a fault in the body's natural defence system against odours. The fault prevents the body from breaking down trimethylamine (TMA), a chemical that is produced in the gut when certain choline-rich foods are digested. 2. What causes TMAU? Trimethylaminuria is caused by a fault in the Flavin-Containing Monooxygenase 3 (FMO3) gene. This gene provides the body with the instructions for making the Flavin-Containing Monooxygenase 3 protein, which is responsible for breaking down TMA. People with TMAU either have a complete absence of the FMO3 protein or have an enzyme that does not work properly. 3. How common is TMAU? TMAU is a rare condition and affects approximately one in 50,000 people in the UK. It occurs in males and females in equal numbers. 4. What are the symptoms of TMAU? Trimethylaminuria is characterised by an offensive body odour that smells like rotting fish, faeces or garbage. The odour is caused by a build-up of TMA in the body. People with TMAU often describe the smell as being 'fishy' or 'like rotting eggs'. Other symptoms of TMAU include: - Fatigue - Depression - Social isolation - Low self-esteem - Neglect - Rage - Feelings of hopelessness 5. How is TMAU diagnosed? Trimethylaminuria is diagnosed using a combination of: - A detailed medical history - Genetic testing - Blood tests 6. What is the treatment for TMAU? There is currently no cure for TMAU. Treatment focuses on managing the symptoms of the condition. This includes: - Dietary changes - Supplements - Treating any co-existing conditions, such as depression 7. What is gene therapy? Gene therapy is a technique used to treat or prevent disease by changing the DNA of a patient

Treatment is aimed at reducing the odor caused by trimethylamine, and improving the patient's quality of life.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1) People don't clench their fists during sleep because it is not an action that the brain has evolved to control. The brain has evolved to control the muscles of mastication (the muscles of the jaw). 2) The jaw is the most common location for clenching because it is the most accessible muscle. It is the only muscle in the body that is always attached to bone (the mandible) and can therefore be clenched at any time.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. The jaw is the most common location for bruxism because of the unique anatomy of the jaw and the absence of a protective cushion of soft tissues between the teeth. 2. The mandible is the only bone in the body that is suspended by muscles, with no cushioning soft tissue between the teeth and the muscle. 3. The temporomandibular joint is the only joint in the body that has no cushioning soft tissues between the bones. This combination of factors makes the jaw the most common location for bruxism.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Sleep bruxism is a parafunctional activity, which means that it is an activity that should not occur during sleep. Sleep bruxism may occur during any stage of sleep, but it is most common during stage N1 sleep. 2. The exact etiology of sleep bruxism is unknown. There are several theories about the origin of bruxism. One of the most accepted theories today is the "stress theory". It postulates that sleep bruxism is a stress-related phenomenon. Sleep bruxism is frequently associated with other parafunctional activities such as snoring, talking, and body movements. 3. During sleep, the jaw muscles and the muscles of mastication are in a state of slight contraction. If the contraction becomes more intense, sleep bruxism may occur. Sleep bruxism is usually not associated with pain in the jaw or teeth. However, if it continues for a long time, it may lead to jaw disorders, headaches, and other problems. 4. Sleep bruxism is usually not treated unless it causes significant problems. Several treatments are available. The most commonly used treatments are oral appliances, such as mouth guards, which are thought to disrupt the grinding pattern. Medications such as benzodiazepines may be used to help relax the jaw muscles. Psychological counseling may also be used to help determine the source of stress and find ways to cope with it.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Plavix (clopidogrel) is used to prevent heart attack, stroke, or other serious conditions in people who have a high risk of these events. This medication is also used to prevent blood clots in people who have been treated with an atherectomy procedure (a procedure to remove fatty deposits from the walls of blood vessels). Clopidogrel is called a platelet inhibitor. Platelets are small blood cells that help form blood clots. Clopidogrel prevents platelets from forming clots. This helps prevent heart attacks, strokes, and other serious conditions. Clopidogrel is taken once a day. Common side effects of clopidogrel include: skin rash, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Taking aspirin and clopidogrel together can increase the risk of bleeding. 2. Linisopril is used to treat high blood pressure. Linisopril is in a class of medications called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. It works by decreasing the production of a substance that causes blood vessels to constrict (get narrower). When blood vessels constrict, blood pressure goes up. 3. Simvastatin is used to lower blood cholesterol level to prevent heart attack, stroke, or other serious conditions. Simvastatin is called a statin. Simvastatin works by decreasing the production of a substance that causes the liver to make cholesterol, and this decreases the amount of cholesterol that may build up in the arteries. 4. Melatonin is a dietary supplement used to treat jet lag and sleep disorders. Melatonin is also used as a sleep aid and to treat insomnia. Melatonin is a natural hormone that is released from the pineal gland in the brain and helps control sleep and wakefulness. Melatonin is not available in the United States as a prescription medication. Melatonin dietary supplements are available as a pill, capsule, tablet, or liquid.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick (hypertrophied). As a result, the heart muscle stiffens and becomes harder to pump blood. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain or palpitations. It can also cause life-threatening heart problems, such as sudden cardiac arrest due to an abnormal heart rhythm. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is often hereditary and is usually diagnosed in people between the ages of 10 and 30. The condition is usually diagnosed with an echocardiogram, which uses sound waves to create images of the heart. Treatment options include medications, lifestyle changes and, in some cases, surgery. 2. Cardiomyopathy - Cardiomyopathy is a disease in which the heart muscle becomes weakened, stretched, or has another structural problem. There are three main types of cardiomyopathy: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy - as described above. Dilated cardiomyopathy - The heart muscle becomes weakened and enlarged. This makes it harder for the heart to pump blood. This is the most common type of cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy - The heart muscle becomes stiff, making it harder for the heart to fill with blood. This can cause problems with the heart's ability to pump blood properly.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation, selective demyelination, and gliosis of CNS.  Although the exact etiology of MS is not known, it is generally accepted that the basic abnormality is an immune-mediated inflammatory response, which results in a lifelong progressive disorder with remissions and relapses. Several lines of evidence suggest that MS is caused by a breach in the immune privilege of the CNS, which results in the infiltration of T lymphocytes and other immune cells into the brain and spinal cord.  The search for a cure for MS has been a long and arduous one. However, to date, no single therapeutic agent has been found to stop the disease progression or reverse signs and symptoms in people with MS.  Although many MS therapies are available, none of them is curative; instead, they are used to control the disease course and manage symptoms.  The most effective way to reduce the impact of MS is to prevent relapses and the progression to disability through use of disease modifying agents.  The current treatment strategy is early treatment of relapses with short courses of high-dose steroids.  The most commonly used DMAs are IFN-beta and GLATI-SE.  The immunosuppressants MITOXANTIN and CYCLOSPORINE are used occasionally.  Future therapeutic approaches will include more specific immune modulators, as well as approaches that target the underlying mechanisms of inflammation, demyelination, and gliosis.  The ultimate goal is to prevent the initial trigger and/or autoimmune response that leads to MS.  The cure for MS will be found when its etiology is understood and an effective prevention strategy is implemented.

It is important to know the stage of the disease and then start treatment. Medications like ocrelizumab, omalizumab, teriflunomide, fingolimod, dimethyl fumarate, dalfampridine, Alemtuzumab, natalizumab are approved by FDA for treatment of multiple sclerosis. These medications have to be taken under the guidance of a neurologist. Please do not worry.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss. MS commonly affects young adults and is a leading cause of disability in the United States. Currently, there is no cure for MS, but several therapies can help reduce clinical relapses and slow the progression of disability. In the past few years, there has been an explosion in the number of approved therapies for treating relapsing forms of MS. This has coincided with a better understanding of the immunopathogenesis of the disease and the recognition that early treatment is paramount. In addition to pharmacologic therapies, rehabilitation, nutritional counseling, and symptomatic therapies are important for patients with MS.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation and demyelination of the central nervous system (CNS).  Currently, there is no cure for MS, although some therapies may help to relieve certain symptoms.  The goals of treatment are to prevent relapses, reduce the frequency of relapses, and delay the progression of disability.  The most common treatments for MS are medications that reduce the immune response, such as corticosteroids and interferons.  Other treatments include monoclonal antibodies, such as natalizumab (Tysabri), which is designed to block the migration of immune cells into the CNS.  Other treatments may help to modify the course of the disease by changing the immune system, nerve growth factors, and neurotransmitters.  Researchers are actively investigating ways to repair the damage caused by MS, including cell transplantation, tissue grafting, and nerve and tissue growth stimulators.  Other strategies under investigation include anti-inflammatory drugs, vaccines, and drugs that downregulate the immune system.  Many experimental and clinical trials for MS are underway around the world.  For example, researchers are investigating a possible cure for MS by transplanting immune system cells that have been changed in the laboratory.  These cells are engineered to attack and destroy only the MS-causing antibodies and T cells.  This procedure is still experimental, however, and is being studied in clinical trials.  The search for a cure for MS continues, but the most effective treatment currently available is rehabilitation.  People with MS can benefit from working with physical therapists, occupational therapists, and speech therapists.  In addition, people with MS often need help in dealing with the emotional and mental stresses associated with the disease.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by destruction of myelin in the central nervous system (CNS). Although the exact cause of MS is not known, the disease is currently thought to result from a combination of genetic susceptibility and environmental factors. MS is usually diagnosed in young adults, with the peak onset at 30 years of age. The clinical course is highly variable, with periods of stability interrupted by recurrent acute attacks. MS is a clinically heterogeneous disease characterized by the following hallmark signs and symptoms: 1) lesions of the CNS that exhibit a well-defined inflammatory process with selective destruction of myelin; 2) areas of partial demyelination (i.e., some myelin present); and 3) variable degrees of neurologic disability. The clinical course of MS is highly variable. The onset is typically in young adults, with a peak onset at 30 years of age. The clinical course is often interrupted by recurrent acute attacks. In general, the clinical course of MS is marked by unpredictable acute attacks followed by variable degrees of recovery and clinical stabilization. However, the clinical course is highly variable, and several subtypes have been described. The clinical course is often divided into four subtypes: relapsing-remitting, secondary progressive, primary progressive, and progressive relapsing. The relapsing-remitting subtype is characterized by unpredictable acute attacks with variable recovery, but with periods of stability between attacks. The secondary progressive subtype begins with a relapsing-remitting course but eventually evolves to a steadily declining neurologic functional level during periods of remission, although superimposed relapses and remissions may still occur. The primary progressive subtype is characterized by a steady neurologic decline from disease onset, with no periods of remission. The progressive relapsing subtype begins with a progressive course that is punctuated by acute attacks.

The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus, often shortened to SLE, is a chronic disease that is difficult to diagnose and treat. Another type, acute cutaneous lupus, usually involves only the skin and is not chronic. Neonatal lupus, which is rare, affects newborns. Finally, drug-induced lupus is caused by medications, most commonly hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid, and quinidine. These medications can cause lupus-like symptoms, but disappear when the medication is stopped. Lupus is caused by a problem with the immune system.  Normally, the immune system protects the body from foreign substances, such as viruses and bacteria. In an autoimmune disease like lupus, the immune system attacks the body's own cells and tissues. In people with lupus, the immune system loses its ability to tell the difference between foreign substances and the body's own cells and tissues. As a result, the immune system makes antibodies that attack the body's own cells and tissues. The parts of the body most affected by lupus are the skin, joints, blood vessels, blood cells, and kidneys. There are many kinds of lupus. The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus, often shortened to SLE, is a chronic disease that is difficult to diagnose and treat. Another type, acute cutaneous lupus, usually involves only the skin and is not chronic. Neonatal lupus, which is rare, affects newborns. Finally, drug-induced lupus is caused by medications, most commonly hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid, and quinidine. These medications can cause lupus-like symptoms, but disappear when the medication is stopped.

1. What triggers the development of leukemia cancer?

The exact cause of leukemia is not known. However, there are risk factors that increase the chances of getting leukemia. These include:

- Genetics: Having a family member with leukemia increases your risk of getting the disease.
- Age: The risk of most types of leukemia, especially AML, increases as you get older.
- Gender: Men are more likely to get ALL and AML than women. Women are more likely to get CLL than men.
- Smoking: Smoking cigarettes increases the risk of developing AML.
- Exposure to chemicals: Exposure to certain chemicals, such as benzene, can increase the risk of getting leukemia.
- Previous Cancer Treatment: Certain types of chemotherapy and radiation therapy for other cancers are linked to a higher risk of getting AML.
- Down Syndrome: Children with Down syndrome have a higher risk of getting leukemia.

Reference: Harrison; 19th edition; Page no: 678

Answer: 2. Can leukemia be overcome?

Leukemia is a cancer of the white blood cells. White blood cells help your body fight infection. Your body makes billions of them every day. In people with leukemia, the bone marrow produces abnormal white blood cells. These abnormal cells crowd out the healthy blood cells. This makes it hard for the blood to carry out its normal functions.

There are different types of leukemia. They are usually grouped into two types:

Acute leukemia: These leukemias are the most common types. They include acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).
Chronic leukemia: These leukemias are the less common types. They include chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

Treatment for leukemia depends on the type and how advanced it is. People with chronic leukemia usually start treatment when they have symptoms. People with acute leukemia need urgent treatment.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. It is one of nine types of muscular dystrophy. The disease is caused by an absence of dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact. Symptoms usually appear before age 6 and may appear as early as infancy. These include difficulty standing up, walking, and crawling. Those with the disorder typically are unable to walk by age 12 and are confined to a wheelchair by age 20. The life expectancy of males with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the late teens or early twenties. It affects about 1 in 3300 newborn males.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder that results in progressive muscle damage. It is the most common and severe form of muscular dystrophy. Symptoms usually appear before age 6 and include delayed development of motor skills, difficulty walking, and a waddling gait. Muscle weakness spreads to the legs, pelvis, and upper body, and eventually affects the muscles that help breathing and swallowing. Most people with the disorder use a wheelchair by age 12. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by a mutation in the DMD gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called dystrophin, which is located primarily in muscles. Researchers think that dystrophin helps keep muscle cells intact. A lack of dystrophin leads to muscle damage and eventual loss of muscle tissue. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. The disease is more common in boys than in girls.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited genetic disorder that involves progressive muscle weakness. It is the most common and most serious type of childhood-onset muscular dystrophy.  The disorder occurs almost exclusively in males. Females can carry the disease gene but usually do not show symptoms.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by an absence of dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact. The condition is typically diagnosed before age 5, when parents may notice that the child has difficulty keeping up with peers in sports and other physical activities.  Symptoms of Duchenne muscular dystrophy usually appear before age 6. Diagnosis is based on a muscle biopsy and genetic testing.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Males have only one copy of the X chromosome and therefore only one copy of the gene for dystrophin. If that copy is altered, the person has the disorder. The disorder is not passed on to sons by their carrier mothers, but all daughters will inherit the condition.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder caused by an inherited defect in the gene responsible for producing dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact. The disease is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Males have only one copy of the X chromosome, while females have two. If a male inherits an abnormal copy of the X chromosome, he will be affected. Females who inherit one abnormal copy of the X chromosome usually do not have symptoms of muscular dystrophy. Muscular dystrophy usually appears in early childhood. The first signs of the disease are often clumsiness and inability to keep up with peers' developmental milestones. The disease can affect many parts of the body, but especially the muscles of the legs, pelvis, and upper body. The most severe form of the disease can result in an inability to walk, breathe, or eat, and can result in death by the age of 20. The disease can be detected at birth by a blood test, and by the age of 6 months by a muscle biopsy. Diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing. No cure or effective treatment exists, but supportive treatment can improve quality of life.

Objectives: To investigate the relationship between IBS and PTSD in a large, population-based sample and to determine the strength of the association between the two conditions. 3. Methods: A cross-sectional study was performed using data from the 2007 National Health Interview Survey. Subjects were asked if they had been diagnosed with IBS by a doctor or other health professional. Subjects were also asked if they had ever been diagnosed with PTSD by a doctor or other health professional. Subjects with a history of IBS or PTSD were asked to report the age at which they were first diagnosed with each condition. Odds ratios (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) were calculated to determine the strength of the association between IBS and PTSD. 4. Results: The study population included 29,461 subjects. Of those, 820 (2.8%) reported a history of IBS and 1,254 (4.2%) reported a history of PTSD. The mean age at diagnosis of IBS was 36.7 years, and the mean age at diagnosis of PTSD was 30.4 years. A history of IBS was associated with a history of PTSD (OR 1.96; 95% CI, 1.64-2.33). This association was strongest among female subjects (OR 2.45; 95% CI, 1.94-2.89) and among subjects 45 to 64 years of age (OR 3.49; 95% CI, 2.54-4.69). 5. Although IBS is a benign condition, it is associated with significant socioeconomic costs, as well as significant psychological distress. 3. PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder with no known structural abnormality. 2. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder that occurs after a traumatic event and is characterized by re-experience of the event, avoidance of stimuli associated with the event, emotional numbing, and hyperarousal. 5. PTSD and IBS share similar psychosocial risk factors and comorbidity. 6. Few studies have investigated the relationship between PTSD and IBS. 7. One study found that 40% of IBS patients met the criteria for PTSD, compared with 20% of the general population. 8. Another study found that 69% of IBS patients with severe symptoms had a lifetime history of PTSD. 9. A third study found that 42% of IBS patients reported a history of PTSD, compared with 12% of the general population. 10. A fourth study found that IBS patients with severe symptoms were more likely to have a history of PTSD than IBS patients with mild symptoms. 11. PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Introduction. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common gastrointestinal disorder that affects up to 15% of the population. 2. Methods. A PubMed search was conducted to identify all studies that have investigated the relationship between IBS and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Inclusion criteria were: (1) studies that examined the relationship between IBS and PTSD in human subjects; (2) studies that were published in English; (3) studies that included a clinical sample; (4) studies that reported at least one prevalence estimate; (5) studies that reported odds ratios (OR) or relative risks (RR) with 95% confidence intervals (CI); (6) studies that were full-text articles or that included a full-text abstract; and (7) studies that were published after 1980. 3. Results.Fifteen studies met the inclusion criteria. The prevalence of PTSD among IBS patients ranged from 17% to 56%, with higher estimates found in tertiary care samples. Estimates of the co-occurrence of PTSD and IBS in the general population ranged from 11% to 28%, with higher estimates found in military samples. Several studies have also investigated the relationship between IBS and PTSD using physician-diagnosed samples. The prevalence of PTSD among IBS patients in these samples ranged from 27% to 55%. 4. Discussion. PTSD is significantly associated with IBS, particularly in tertiary care samples. Estimates of the co-occurrence of PTSD and IBS in the general population vary widely. More research is needed to clarify the relationship between PTSD and IBS in community samples.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a chronic gastrointestinal disorder of unknown etiology, affecting millions of people worldwide. 2. The symptoms of PTSD can develop after a range of traumatic events, including sexual assault, warfare, traffic collisions and other threats on a person's life. 4. Symptoms may include disturbing thoughts, feelings, or dreams related to the events; mental or physical distress to trauma-related cues; attempts to avoid trauma-related cues; alterations in how a person thinks and feels; and changes in how a person behaves. 5. A person with PTSD is at a higher risk for suicide and intentional self-harm. 6. The diagnosis is made by a health care professional with the patient's self-reported symptoms being the most reliable indicator. 7. Treatment is typically by a combination of pharmacological and psychological methods. 8. No specific treatment is known, but medications are often used to help with specific symptoms. Psychological treatments are aimed at relieving symptoms through a variety of means, but benzodiazepines and beta blockers can also be used. 9. Some people may develop PTSD-like symptoms within three months of a traumatic event but this is not necessarily so. This group is sometimes said to have "acute stress disorder". 10. The disorder may last for many years and, in some cases, is a chronic condition.

1. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder, and its pathophysiology is still not fully understood. 2. The co-occurrence of IBS and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has not been investigated sufficiently to date. 3. The aim of this study was to investigate the co-occurrence of IBS and PTSD in a group of patients with PTSD and compare them with a control group of patients with IBS and no PTSD. 4. The study included 120 patients with PTSD and 120 patients with IBS. Patients with PTSD were divided into two groups: those with and those without co-occurring IBS. Patients with PTSD and IBS were compared to the group with IBS only. 5. Patients with PTSD and IBS did not differ from patients with IBS only in terms of demographic data and clinical symptoms. However, patients with PTSD and IBS were characterized by higher levels of depression, anxiety, and somatization, as well as greater severity of symptoms and impairment of functioning. 6. The results of the study suggest that IBS should be considered as a potential biological marker of PTSD. Further research is needed to investigate the biological mechanisms underlying the co-occurrence of these disorders.

Patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer should receive chemotherapy.

Radiation therapy can be used for palliation of pain in patients with metastatic disease.

The pathophysiology of asthma is complex and involves many cell types and several mediators. 3. The chronic inflammation is associated with airway hyper-responsiveness that leads to recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness and coughing particularly at night. 4. Asthma is best controlled by avoiding exposure to irritants and allergens and by pharmacological agents that may be required to achieve this. 5. The goals of asthma treatment are: a. Prevent chronic and troublesome symptoms b. Reduce the occurrence and severity of exacerbations c. Minimize the need for emergency treatment d. Provide optimal pharmacotherapy with minimal side effects e. Optimize the patient's well-being and ability to function normally; and f. Reduce mortality. 6. Current treatment guidelines emphasize the control of asthma symptoms, prevention of exacerbations, and minimization of the side-effects of treatment. 7. The treatment of asthma should be individualized. Factors to be considered include the patient's symptoms, spirometry results, and medication history. 8. The three-pronged approach to the management of asthma includes: a. Environmental control measures b. Pharmacological therapy; and c. Patient education. 9. Environmental control measures are essential in the management of asthma. a. Environmental control measures should be considered for all patients with asthma. b. Environmental control measures should be an integral part of the management of all patients with asthma. 10. Environmental control measures should be specifically targeted to the allergen or the trigger identified as relevant to the individual patient. 11. Environmental control measures should be recommended for patients with persistent asthma. 12. Environmental control measures should be recommended for patients with mild intermittent asthma if they have: a. Triggers that are difficult to avoid b. Triggers for which environmental control measures are simple

An inguinal hernia can be congenital, meaning it is present at birth.7. An inguinal hernia can be the result of a weakness in the abdominal wall muscles that is caused by disease (such as cystic fibrosis) or injury.8. An inguinal hernia can be a result of a disease that causes an increase in abdominal fluid (such as fluid build-up due to heart problems)9. Lynch syndrome is caused by a mutation in the MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2 (DNA repair genes). 3. In most cases, Lynch syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. In some cases, the condition occurs due to a new mutation in one of the affected genes, and in these cases, the disorder is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. 4. Individuals with Lynch syndrome should have a colonoscopy every year, beginning at age 20 (or 10 years before the youngest age at which colorectal cancer was diagnosed in the family). A colonoscopy is an exam used to look inside the colon for signs of cancer. 5. Women with Lynch syndrome should have an endometrial biopsy every year, beginning at age 30 (or 10 years before the youngest age at which endometrial cancer was diagnosed in the family). An endometrial biopsy is a test to take a small sample of the lining of the uterus (endometrium) to look for cancer cells. Women with a family history of Lynch syndrome may consider having a hysterectomy (surgery to remove the uterus) and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (surgery to remove the fallopian tubes and ovaries) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial and ovarian cancer.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Glaucoma is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness in the United States. It usually happens when the eye pressure increases. This increased pressure may be due to:  - Increased fluid production  - Decreased fluid drainage  - Fluid is unable to drain from the eye  The increased pressure may cause damage to the optic nerve. It usually happens slowly, so you may not notice changes in your vision until the glaucoma has caused significant damage.  The goal of glaucoma treatment is to lower eye pressure. Medicines, laser surgery, and glaucoma surgery can all help protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  NIH: National Eye Institute
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Yes, glaucoma is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness in the United States. It is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  How does glaucoma damage the optic nerve?  Increased pressure inside the eye (intraocular pressure) is the main cause of optic nerve damage in glaucoma. This increased pressure usually occurs in the back of the eye. The fluid in the eye flows through a clear channel to the angle where the iris and cornea meet.  There, the fluid leaves the eye, and more fluid flows in. When the fluid reaches a damaged angle, it cannot flow out as easily. The excess fluid builds up, putting pressure on the optic nerve. This pressure can cause the nerve fibers to die, and eventually destroy the optic nerve.  How is glaucoma diagnosed?  Early glaucoma has no symptoms. That's why glaucoma is called "the silent thief of sight." As the disease progresses, you may notice a slight loss of peripheral vision.  Your eye care professional will diagnose glaucoma with a comprehensive eye exam that measures the pressure in your eye and tests how well your optic nerve is functioning.  What are the treatments for glaucoma?  To protect your eyes against vision loss, it's important to treat glaucoma before your optic nerve is damaged.  The most common treatment for glaucoma is prescription eyedrops. Sometimes, eyedrops are not enough to control the pressure in the eye. Your eye doctor may prescribe laser surgery to reduce the pressure in the eye. If you have glaucoma, your eye doctor will prescribe eyedrops, oral medications, or surgery to protect your eyes against vision loss.

They seem to be looking through a tunnel. Over time, the tunnel will get narrower and narrower. 15. This will result in blindness. 16. If caught early, glaucoma can usually be controlled. 17. Treatments can include prescription eyedrops, glaucoma surgery, or a combination of both.

To protect yourself against glaucoma, you should get regular eye exams. You should also tell your doctor about any medicines or eye drops you are using. PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Spina Bifida: a. In the absence of a neural tube defect, spina bifida occulta usually requires no treatment. b. When the defect is large enough to allow protrusion of the spinal cord or spinal nerves, surgical closure of the defect is indicated. The objective is to prevent damage to the cord or nerves by exposure to the environment. c. Surgical closure is performed as soon after birth as possible; the earlier the defect is closed, the better the prognosis. Spina bifida is treated by neurosurgical closure of the defect and postoperative antibiotic therapy. d. Postoperative shunting of CSF may be required to relieve hydrocephalus. 2. Vertebral fusion: a. A fixed, progressive deformity of the spine is an indication for surgery. b. Surgery is usually performed after skeletal maturity. Fusion of the spine in a deformed position can lead to a second deformity, which is often more severe than the first. c. Surgery should be directed at correcting both the primary and secondary deformities. 3. Syringomyelia: a. Surgical treatment of syringomyelia is indicated when a definite neurologic deficit can be attributed to the syrinx. b. The most common surgical approach is a posterior decompression with or without a duraplasty. The rationale for posterior decompression is that a syrinx develops in the area of cerebellar or dorsal brainstem tissue within the spinal cord and, therefore, should be approached posteriorly. c. Other surgical approaches have included anterior surgery, and in some cases, a combined anterior and posterior approach has been used.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) Surgical approach: The surgical treatment of the syrinx is the most commonly used treatment. It involves the placement of a shunt to drain the fluid from the syrinx into the peritoneal cavity. This shunt may be placed from either the ventricles (ventriculoperitoneal shunt) or directly into the syrinx (syringoperitoneal shunt). 2) Endoscopic third ventriculostomy: This procedure is performed to drain the fluid from the syrinx by creating a new opening in the floor of the third ventricle (foramina of Luschka). 3) Chiari decompression: This procedure is performed to release the pressure on the cervical spinal cord by removing the posterior arch of the atlas. 4) Vertebral column resection: This procedure is performed to correct the deformity of the vertebral column. 5) Ultrasound destruction of syrinx: This procedure is performed to destroy the syrinx by using focused ultrasound energy. 6) Intrathecal antibiotic treatment: This procedure is performed to inject antibiotics directly into the CSF to treat infections.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4:
2006 was a pivotal year in the history of ovarian cancer research. That year, the Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) Research Network published a landmark paper that would forever change the way scientists and physicians viewed ovarian cancer. The paper, entitled Detection of somatic copy number alterations in the cancer genome project, described the first whole-genome characterization of a major human cancer. The researchers used DNA microarrays to analyze the entire genome of 11,000 tumors from 11 different types of cancer, including 400 ovarian cancers. They discovered that ovarian cancers have the highest genetic diversity of any cancer type, with each tumor harboring an average of 600 mutations. The researchers also found that the mutations accumulated gradually over time, allowing the cells to evade the immune system by reducing the expression of tumor antigens. In addition, they found that the mutations clustered in only a few genomic "hotspots," suggesting that only a handful of genes are mutated repeatedly in ovarian cancers. This discovery could help scientists develop new drugs that target specific mutations in these genes.

Since the publication of this paper, researchers have worked tirelessly to uncover the molecular underpinnings of ovarian cancer. Scientists at the University of Washington, for example, discovered that a protein called ID4 regulates the activity of cancer-causing genes called p53 and k-ras. They also found that ID4 is frequently downregulated in ovarian cancers, leading to the overactivation of these genes and the development of cancer.

Answer: Yes

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Riluzole: Riluzole is the only medication that has been proved to prolong life in patients with ALS. It seems to slow the progression of ALS by interfering with the damage to motor neurons. Riluzole is a safe medication with relatively few side effects. 2. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Some ALS patients may benefit from treatment with NSAIDs. Studies have shown that the NSAID sodium thiopental may help slow the progression of the disease. Ibuprofen and other NSAIDs may also be effective. 3. Pyridostigmine (Mestinon): This medication is sometimes used to treat the symptoms of weakness and muscle cramps in the arms and legs. 4. Prednisone: This medication, which is also known as a glucocorticoid, is often used to treat weakness caused by inflammation. 5. Azathioprine: This immunosuppressive medication is sometimes used to treat ALS. It is thought to work by reducing the immune response that may be causing damage to motor neurons. 6. Mexiletine: This anti-arrhythmic medication is sometimes used to relieve some of the symptoms of ALS. It is thought to work by suppressing the spontaneous firing of motor neurons. 7. Zanaflex (tizanidine): This medication is sometimes used to relieve spasticity in patients with ALS. 8. Baclofen: This muscle relaxant is sometimes used to treat spasticity in patients with ALS. 9. Epidural steroid injections. These are injections of steroids into the space around the spinal cord. They are sometimes used to relieve pain and improve function in patients with ALS. 10. Symptomatic treatment: In addition to medications, there are a number of other things that can be done to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life for people with ALS. These include: good nutrition and hydration, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, a good bowel and bladder program, and adequate pain management.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Riluzole. Riluzole (100 mg twice daily) was approved for ALS because it provides a modest survival benefit (by about 2-3 months). Riluzole probably exerts its beneficial effects by interfering with the processes of programmed cell death. Side effects are few and include fatigue and gastrointestinal upset; it is also hepatotoxic. 2. Symptomatic Therapy. Symptoms in ALS are treated as they arise. The two most common symptoms, pain and depression, are managed with pharmacologic agents. Pain is usually treated with standard analgesics, but the management of neuropathic pain may require agents such as gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine, or amitriptyline. Depression may respond to any of a number of antidepressant medications. 3. Nutrition. The American Academy of Neurology has concluded that enteral nutrition (that is, feeding tubes) should not be used routinely in patients with ALS, but rather should be considered on a case-by-case basis. In patients who are aspirating, if a trial of non-oral feeding is successful, a gastrostomy or gastrojejunostomy tube should be placed. 4. Glucocorticoids. In a large, controlled, prospective study, glucocorticoids were shown to improve the overall survival of patients with ALS. Treatment was most effective when therapy was started early. The authors of this study recommend that patients with ALS be treated with 10 mg of prednisone per day or 40 mg of azathioprine per day. These agents are to be used with the intention of slowing progression, not with the hope of reversing weakness. 5. Other Agents. A number of other agents have been tested in ALS without clear evidence of efficacy. These include vitamin E, coenzyme Q10, oxcarbazepine, and calcium channel blockers.

Creatine and Coenzyme Q10: These are supplements that have been widely used by ALS patients based on anecdotal reports of efficacy. However, a large randomized trial failed to demonstrate any benefit in ALS patients taking creatine and Coenzyme Q10. 4. Cigarette smoking: Cigarette smoking has been shown to be associated with a lower risk of ALS. However, there is no evidence that cigarette smoking is protective once a patient has developed ALS. 5. High-dose steroids: A randomized, placebo-controlled trial failed to demonstrate any benefit in ALS patients treated with high-dose steroids. 6. Other medications: Medications that have been tried in ALS without any evidence of efficacy include: thyroid hormone, growth hormone, vitamin E, vitamin C, copper, zinc, anti-oxidants, and pentoxifylline. 7. Foods: There is no evidence that any specific food is protective in ALS.

Enlightment: If you have been bitten by a tick and develop symptoms of fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash several days after the tick bite, you may have Lyme disease. If you find a tick attached to your body, remove it promptly. Lyme disease is caused by a spirochete, Borrelia burgdorferi, and is transmitted to humans by the bite of a small Ixodes tick. The disease is a zoonosis, with deer and other mammals serving as the major reservoir. The characteristic skin manifestation, erythema chronicum migrans (ECM), begins as a red macule or papule and expands slowly over days to weeks to form a large round lesion with central clearing and a red, raised border. Other early manifestations include facial palsy, meningismus, and acute myocarditis. If untreated, later manifestations include arthralgias, arthritis, and encephalopathy. Treatment is with penicillin or tetracycline.

Nicotine affects digestion and absorption through multiple mechanisms. It increases gastric acid secretion, delays gastric emptying, and increases intestinal motility. These effects are mediated via nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Nicotine also increases intestinal absorption of non-nutrient or nutrient compounds, possibly via dopamine receptors. The effects of nicotine on digestion and absorption are dose-dependent. At low doses (< 10 mg), nicotine stimulates the central nervous system and causes an increase in appetite and thirst. At high doses (> 15 mg), the effects of nicotine on digestion and absorption predominate. The effects of nicotine on digestion and absorption are not mediated by nicotine addiction, as nicotine-naive individuals also exhibit these effects.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 3-SCA3 is a rare genetic disorder that causes ataxia and other neurological problems. It is related to the more common disorder called Machado-Joseph Disease. The symptoms of SCA3 usually begin in middle age. They include:  Trouble walking and uncoordinated movements (ataxia).  Muscle stiffness (dystonia).  Problems with eye movements.  Speech problems.  Slow movement and stiffness in the limbs.  Tremors.  Tight muscles (spasticity).  Other symptoms may include:  Difficulty swallowing.  Dementia.  Depression.  Muscle spasms.  Seizures.  Sleep disturbances.  Weakness.  Some people also have symptoms of the related disorder, Machado-Joseph Disease, such as:  Dysarthria.  Facial muscle weakness.  Gait disturbance.  Generalized muscle stiffness.  Oculomotor abnormalities.  Tongue fasciculations.  The cause of SCA3 is a mutation in the ATN1 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called ataxin-1. Researchers believe that this protein plays a role in regulating gene expression. Ataxin-1 is involved in many processes, including the development and function of the nervous system. Researchers think that problems with ataxin-1 cause SCA3.  Scientists have identified mutations in the ATN1 gene in people with SCA3. Diagnosis is based on symptoms and genetic testing. There is no cure for SCA3. Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms.  Ataxia-telangiectasia The Ataxia Telangiectasia Group
