PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Cold sores are caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1. The first time you are infected with this virus, the condition is called primary herpes. You may have no signs or symptoms, or you may have a variety of symptoms, including a headache, fever, and swollen lymph nodes in your neck. It may take 2 weeks or longer for the sores to heal. After you are exposed to the virus, the condition is called recurrent herpes. Your symptoms may be mild, or you may have a severe outbreak, with many sores that are painful and slow to heal.  Cold sores typically start with a tingling or burning sensation, followed by the formation of a small, raised, and sometimes itchy bump or blister. This bump gradually becomes a painful ulcer about 1/2 to 1 inch in size. The cold sore is usually located on the lip, but it can appear anywhere on the mouth or on the skin around the mouth. The blister usually breaks open and forms a crusty scab. Cold sores typically heal without treatment in 7 to 10 days.  Over-the-counter medications can relieve the pain and discomfort of cold sores. These include ointments that numb the blister, antibacterial ointments that prevent infection, and ointments that soften the crust and help it fall off. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) can relieve the pain of cold sores. You should not use aspirin if you have a cold sore because it can lead to a serious condition called Reye syndrome.  Antiviral medications, such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir, can relieve symptoms and shorten the healing time if they are started early in the outbreak, usually within 24 hours of the appearance of the first blister. These medications are most effective when taken prescribed by your doctor.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Wash your hands thoroughly after touching cold sores.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: Cold sores are caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1. There is no cure for cold sores, but you can ease symptoms and reduce the risk of infecting others by:  - Avoiding sexual contact when you have a cold sore.  - Washing your hands often, especially before and after meals.  - Avoiding kissing, especially on the lips.  - Using your own toothbrush, razor, and towels.  - Avoiding sharing drinking glasses, silverware, and napkins.  - Washing dishes and utensils with soap and hot water.  - Using an over-the-counter antiseptic mouthwash.  You may also apply a topical antiviral medication to shorten the duration of the lesion and reduce the risk of infecting others.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. HIV is treated with a combination of antiretroviral medicines.2. There are five classes of ARV drugs: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), Nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NtRTIs), Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs), Protease inhibitors (PIs), and Integrase inhibitors (IIs).3. The choice of drugs is individualized based on the patient's viral load, CD4 count, and clinical stage of HIV disease, as well as the patient's age, pregnancy status, prior antiretroviral drug history, and medical comorbidities.4. HIV is treated with a combination of three or more ARV drugs.5. The most commonly used combinations include two NRTIs with either a PI or an NNRTI.6. The combination of two NRTIs with a PI is known as "highly active antiretroviral therapy" (HAA).7. The majority of HIV-infected individuals who are receiving HAA regimens will achieve a clinical and immunologic response within the first 6 months of treatment.8. The goals of HAA are to:a. Suppress HIV replication as evidenced by plasma HIV RNA levels less than the lower limit of quantitation (LLOQ),b. Increase CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts, andc. Reduce the risk of opportunistic infections and malignancies.9. A patient is considered to have a "successful response" to HAA if virologic suppression (plasma HIV RNA levels less than the LLOQ) is achieved and maintained for 2-3 years post-treatment.10. The most common side effects of NRTIs are a. Bone marrow suppression, manifested as anemia and neutropenia, and b. Lipodystrophy.11. The most common side effects of PIs are a. Lipodystrophy and metabolic complications such as dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and fat redistribution, and b. Gastrointestinal symptoms
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. The standard of care for HIV-positive individuals is to start antiretroviral therapy (ART), also known as combination antiretroviral therapy (cART). This consists of a combination of three or more drugs, which are usually a combination of two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and either a protease inhibitor (PI) or a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). 2. The goal of treatment is to reduce the viral load to an undetectable level (less than 50 copies/mL) and to prevent the progression of HIV to acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). 3. The first drug that should be initiated in treatment-naive patients is a combination of two NRTIs. 4. The recommended preferred PIs are ritonavir-boosted lopinavir (in combination with two NRTIs) and ritonavir-boosted atazanavir (in combination with two NRTIs or one NRTI and a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI)). 5. The recommended preferred NNRTIs are efavirenz (in combination with two NRTIs) and nevirapine (in combination with two NRTIs or one NRTI and a PI). 6. The recommended preferred integrase strand transfer inhibitors (INSTIs) are raltegravir (in combination with two NRTIs) and elvitegravir (in combination with two NRTIs). 7. The recommended preferred entry inhibitors are maraviroc (in combination with two NRTIs) and enfuvirtide (in combination with two NRTIs). 8. The recommended preferred protease inhibitors are atazanavir (in combination with two NRTIs), fosamprenavir (in combination with two NRTIs), and darunavir (in combination with two NRTIs). 9. PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Hi, Miranda, I am glad to hear that you are working on this issue. HIV treatment has advanced a lot in the last few years. It used to be that HIV positive people would take one pill a day. Now, there are several options. The first option is to take one pill a day. The second option is to take two pills a day, one in the morning and one in the evening. The third option is to take three pills a day, one in the morning, one in the afternoon, and one in the evening. The fourth option is to take two pills in the morning, one in the morning and one in the afternoon. There are also several new medicines that are very powerful, and they have fewer side effects. The most important thing is that HIV positive people should be very adherent to taking their medicines every day. Missing doses can lead to the virus developing resistance to the medicine, and it will no longer work. Hope this helps.

6. As an Airport employee interacting with hundreds daily, when can I safely resume work without exposing others to Shingles?

Shingles is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in individuals who have had chickenpox in the past. It presents with a unilateral vesicular dermatomal eruption, which may be associated with severe pain. Shingles is contagious during the vesicular phase through direct contact or respiratory secretions. Patients are contagious until all lesions have crusted. The risk of transmission is greatest during the first 2 to 3 weeks after the rash appears. There is no specific treatment for shingles. Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) may be used in immunocompromised patients or those over 60 years of age. Treatment of pain is with analgesics (ibuprofen, acetaminophen, or opiates). Pain that does not respond to treatment with analgesics is treated with anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin, carbamazepine). Shingles vaccine is recommended for individuals over 60 years of age. In healthy individuals, it reduces the incidence of shingles by 51% and the incidence of post-herpetic neuralgia by 66%. Since the vaccine is only effective against the causative agent (VZV), it is not effective in the treatment of active shingles.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Sleep Apnea is a disorder that occurs when there is a cessation of breathing during sleep.2. Symptoms of Sleep Apnea include excessive daytime sleepiness, loud snoring / snorting, interrupted sleep, morning headaches, fatigue, depression, personality changes, impotence or menstrual irregularities.3. Sleep Apnea is caused due to obstruction of the upper airway during sleep.4. The most common cause of Sleep Apnea is obesity, however it can also occur due to anatomical abnormalities of the upper airway, hypothyroidism, acromegaly, amyloidosis, neuromuscular conditions or malformation of the jaw bones.5. Sleep Apnea is diagnosed using an overnight sleep study or polysomnography.6. Sleep Apnea can be treated using Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP).7. PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). CLL is a slow-growing blood and bone marrow disease that usually occurs during or after middle age. The disease is most often found during a routine blood test. There may be no signs or symptoms in the early stages of CLL. Early signs of CLL may include fatigue, enlarged lymph nodes, and weight loss. As the disease gets worse, the patient may have fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The spleen and liver may get larger. There is no cure for CLL, but medicines may help keep it from spreading.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3:
Because the term "diabetes" is a MeSH (Medical Subject Headings) term, and the search strategy utilized MeSH terms. 
MeSH terms are developed and maintained by the National Library of Medicine. They are used to index articles in the MEDLINE database, which is one of the databases used by PubMed. 
When you search using a MeSH term, PubMed searches for all articles that are indexed with that specific MeSH term. 
In contrast, if you search using a non-MeSH term, PubMed will not find all the articles on that topic that are indexed in MEDLINE. 
That is why the search for "diabetes" found more articles than the search for "hypertension" and "fibromyalgia," even though the latter are more commonly searched for terms.

1. What is familial Mediterranean fever?

Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis (inflammation of serous membranes). It is typically associated with abdominal pain, joint pain, and fever. Most people with FMF develop their first symptoms as children or young adults. FMF is most commonly seen in people of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins. However, anyone can develop this condition.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis. 2. It is a genetic disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. 3. The condition is most common in individuals of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins. 4. The gene associated with FMF is called pyrin (or marenostrin). 5. The most common symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, and pain in the joints. 6. Other symptoms may include rash, headache, and nausea. 7. Episodes of fever and pain typically last less than 72 hours. 8. Between episodes, affected individuals usually feel normal. 9. FMF is diagnosed based on a person's symptoms. 10. There is no specific treatment, but certain medications may reduce the frequency and severity of attacks.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The condition is characterized by recurrent fever accompanied by abdominal pain, headaches and inflammation of the serosal membranes (pleura, pericardium, synovium). 2. It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the MEFV gene. 3. In most cases, the condition is benign, but in some cases it can cause amyloidosis, renal failure and cystic fibrosis of the pancreas. 4. The treatment is symptomatic during the attacks and prophylactic therapy with colchicine. 5. Colchicine is effective in preventing the attacks and relieving the symptoms of patients. 6. In patients with renal failure, colchicine is ineffective and the only option is to perform a renal transplant.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Familial Mediterranean Fever is a condition characterized by recurrent attacks of fever accompanied by inflammation of the peritoneum (the lining of the abdomen), pleura (the lining of the lungs), or synovial membrane of the joints. The condition is most common among people of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins. Symptoms usually appear during childhood and become more frequent and severe with age. The attacks of fever, which last for one or several days, are often accompanied by pain in the abdomen, chest, or joints. The attacks are separated by symptom-free periods that can last for weeks, months, or even years. The acute attacks can be severe and require hospitalization. In some cases, amyloidosis (the accumulation of abnormal protein in tissue) develops. In rare cases, there is a fatal outcome due to the development of an inflammatory reaction in the serous membranes (mesothelial) lining the internal organs (mesothelioma).
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis (inflammation of serous membranes) and, occasionally, rash and headaches. 2. FMF is an autosomal recessive disease that most commonly occurs in people of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins. 3. The gene for FMF is called pyrin (for its relation to fever) and encodes a protein of the same name. 4. The protein is a component of the inflammasome, a multiprotein complex that plays a central role in innate immunity and inflammation by recognizing various microbial products and stimulating the production of the cytokine IL-1. 5. Clinical features of FMF include the following: a. Attacks of fever and serositis that last 12 to 72 hours b. Precipitation by surgery, infection, or emotional stress c. Attacks may be associated with headaches, rash, and aseptic meningitis d. Eosinophilia and leukocytosis may be present during attacks e. Amino aciduria (particularly for cysteine) and hematuria may be present between attacks f. Renal function is normal 6. Diagnosis is based on the patient's history and the exclusion of other causes of amyloidosis. 7. Treatment with colchicine, 0.5 mg twice daily, prevents attacks and reduces the risk for amyloidosis.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1) If your arrhythmia is causing symptoms or is detected with tests, your doctor may recommend one or more of the following treatments: Medications. Your doctor may prescribe medications to control your heart rate or to reduce the risk of developing a potentially harmful arrhythmia. These medications may include beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and digoxin. Electrical shock. In some cases, your doctor may recommend using an electrical shock to restore a normal heart rhythm. This procedure is called cardioversion. If your arrhythmia is caused by a reversible problem, such as an overdose of a medication or an electrolyte imbalance, cardioversion may be the only treatment you need. Surgery. If your arrhythmia is caused by a structural problem, such as scarring from a previous heart attack or a malformed heart valve, your doctor may recommend surgery to correct the problem. This may involve creating a pacemaker to trigger heartbeats, or replacing or repairing a malformed valve. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) and pacemakers. These devices can monitor your heart rhythm and deliver an electrical shock when you need it. If you have a history of arrhythmias or other heart problems, your doctor may recommend an ICD or a pacemaker to help prevent sudden cardiac death.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) is a procedure used to treat certain types of arrhythmias. During the procedure, your doctor will use an electrode catheter to deliver energy to the area of your heart that causes the arrhythmia. The energy destroys the abnormal heart tissue and helps prevent the arrhythmia from occurring. Radiofrequency ablation is often the preferred treatment for people who don't respond to medications or for those who have recurrent or severe arrhythmias. 2. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) is a small, battery-powered device that constantly monitors your heart rate and rhythm. If a very fast, irregular heartbeat or a life-threatening arrhythmia occurs, the device delivers a jolt of electricity to restore your heartbeat to a normal rhythm. 3. Pacemaker is a small, battery-powered device that sends electrical signals to your heart to treat a slow heartbeat. If you have a heartbeat that is too slow, a pacemaker can help.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. The latest therapy for heart arrhythmia is called catheter ablation. It is a nonsurgical treatment that uses heat to destroy the abnormal heart tissue causing the arrhythmia. 2. During the procedure, a doctor places a catheter (a long, thin, flexible tube) into an artery in your groin or arm and threads it to your heart. 3. Radio waves or cold energy is used to destroy the abnormal heart tissue. 4. The procedure usually takes 2-4 hours, and you'll spend the night in the hospital for observation. 5. You'll recover from the procedure in about 2 weeks. 6. Catheter ablation is a good treatment option for people with heart arrhythmias who don't respond to medications or can't tolerate them. It's also an option for people who have recurrent arrhythmias or have an inappropriate implanardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) shock.

Ablation: Ablation is a procedure that uses energy (heat or cold) to remove or destroy tissue. Radiofrequency ablation and cryoablation are the two most common types of ablation used to treat heart rhythm disorders. 3. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Dear Mehrnaz, Lupus is a chronic disease that can affect any part of the body, but usually affects the skin, joints, blood vessels and organs. It can be mild or severe. The goals of treatment are to:  prevent flares  treat flares when they occur  reduce damage to joints and organs  reduce pain and other symptoms  help you live your life to the fullest.  There is no cure for lupus, but medications and lifestyle changes can help control it.  The treatment depends on severity, which is judged by how many organs are affected by lupus, and by blood tests.  People with mild disease may need only NSAIDs for pain and sometimes a short course of steroids. People with more severe disease need steroids, immunosuppressant medications, and sometimes other drugs.  The most commonly used medications for lupus are:  steroids such as prednisone,  Hydroxychloroquine,  Mycophenolate mofetil,  Azathioprine,  Methotrexate,  Cyclophosphamide,  IV immunoglobulin, and  Rituximab.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Lupus is a chronic disease that can affect any part of the body, but mostly affects the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, and brain.  There are many kinds of lupus. The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects many parts of the body. Discoid lupus, another type, causes a rash that doesn't go away. Subacute cutaneous lupus causes sores after being out in the sun. Another type can be caused by medication. Neonatal lupus, which is rare, affects newborns.   Anyone can get lupus, but women are most at risk. Lupus is also more common in African American, Hispanic, Asian, and Native American women than in Caucasian women. The cause of lupus is not known.  Lupus has many symptoms. Some common ones are joint pain or swelling, muscle pain, fatigue, and skin rashes. Other symptoms include fever, chest pain when taking a deep breath, and sensitivity to the sun. There are also many other symptoms.  Lupus is usually diagnosed by a blood test and, sometimes, a skin test. There is no one specific test for lupus. The diagnosis is made from many factors, including the symptoms, physical exam, and blood tests. There is no cure for lupus, but medications and other treatments can help control it.

Antimalarial drugs are also used to treat lupus. These medications were originally developed to treat malaria but have been shown to be effective in treating lupus as well. 2) Lifestyle Changes: In addition to medications, there are several lifestyle changes that someone diagnosed with lupus can make to help manage their symptoms. Regular exercise, a healthy diet, and getting enough rest and relaxation can all help manage symptoms of lupus. It is also important to avoid smoking and excessive drinking of alcohol.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 5-HT Derivatives as Antiparasitic Agents - The 5-HT derivatives are effective antiparasitic agents against a wide range of parasites. They are active against both platyhelminths and cestodes. The 5-HT derivatives are more effective against tapeworms than against flukes, and the activity against the former is highly specific. The 5-HT derivatives are effective against the tapeworms Taenia saginata, Taenia solium, Diphyllobothrium latum, Hymenolepis nana, and Hymenolepis diminuta. They are also active against the cestodes Dipylidium caninum, Spirometra mansoni, and Echinococcus granulosus. The 5-HT derivatives are ineffective against Schistosoma spp., and Trichinella spiralis. 5-HT derivatives are the treatment of choice for Taenia saginata, and are highly effective against the other tapeworms mentioned above. They are also the treatment of choice for the treatment of D. caninum, and Spirometra mansoni. However, for the treatment of E. granulosus, the benzimidazoles are more effective than the 5-HT derivatives. The 5-HT derivatives are highly effective against H. nana and H. diminuta, and are the treatment of choice for these infections. The 5-HT derivatives are highly specific for their parasitic targets, and have very low toxicity for mammalian cells. The 5-HT derivatives are well tolerated, and side effects are rare. They are highly effective treatments for parasitic infections.

Do you take any medicines or drugs? If you answer "yes" to the first question and "no" to the others, you may have a condition called erectile dysfunction. This is the inability to get or keep an erection hard enough to have sex. It's a common problem, affecting up to 1 in 3 men.  If you answer "no" to the first question and "yes" to one or more of the others, you may have another type of problem called premature ejaculation. This is when a man reaches orgasm and ejaculates too quickly, often before his penis is even erect.  Premature ejaculation is common, particularly with a new partner. It also may occur only in certain sexual situations or if it has been a long time since the last ejaculation.  Both erectile dysfunction and premature ejaculation may be related to psychological factors, such as worry and anxiety. For example, worry about poor performance may cause you to become so distracted that you cannot have an erection or stay erect.  Stress may also play a role. For example, stress may interfere with sexual function, and illness or medicines also may cause problems.  Certain medical conditions and lifestyle choices also may contribute to erectile dysfunction or premature ejaculation. These include the following:  - Diabetes  - High blood pressure  - High cholesterol  - Heart disease  - Stroke  - Nerve damage (neuropathy) from diabetes, chronic alcoholism, or other causes  - Drug or alcohol addiction  - Tobacco smoking  - Obesity  - Age  - Lack of exercise  - Stress  - Long-term relationships  - Low testosterone levels  - Certain medicines  If you have persistent erectile dysfunction or premature ejaculation, you should see your doctor. The problem should not be ignored because it may be a symptom of other serious disorders.  Your doctor will diagnose erectile dysfunction or premature ejaculation from your medical history

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Indications for HBO: Meniere's disease is a clinical diagnosis. The definite diagnosis of Meniere's disease is based on the patients history, clinical findings and audiometry. The following criteria must be satisfied for the diagnosis of Meniere's disease: a. History of episodic vertigo, associated with auditory symptoms, sensation of aural fullness and fluctuating hearing loss. b. Audiometric findings: SNHL of at least 10 dB in 510 Hz and 10 dB in 1000 Hz, with at least 10 dB difference between the two ears. The degree of hearing loss may fluctuate and it is not uncommon to find a marked degree of hearing loss in one test and minimal loss in another. Fluctuating hearing loss is the most characteristic feature of Meniere's disease. c. Caloric tests: Unilateral or bilateral reduced response (by 20-30%) or a reduced and unstable response (by 10-20%) on the involved side. d. Tone decay test: Decay of less than 15 dB in 5 dB steps. 2. Contraindications: Otosclerosis, acoustic neuroma, vestibular schwannoma, active middle or inner ear infection. 3. Treatment modalities: Medical treatment: Antihistaminic, anticholinergics, sedatives, diuretics, vasodilators, serotonin antagonists, calcium channel blockers, beta blockers. Surgical treatment: Intermittent low pressure pulse therapy, endolymphatic sac surgery, surgical destruction of vestibular labyrinth, cochlear implantation, genetic therapy. Hyperbaric oxygen: It is a non-invasive method for treating Meniere's disease. It is a method of treatment which deserves more attention because of its efficiency and low cost. The treatment protocol consists of daily or alternate day sessions of 90 min. each, with the patient breathing 100% oxygen at a pressure of 2.0 MPa (2.5 ATA). The treatment is given in a multiplace hyperbaric chamber
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. The pathophysiology of Meniere's Disease is still not well understood. 2. The most accepted theory is the "Endolymphatic Hydrops" which suggests that there is a dilation of the endolymphatic system causing an increase in volume of the endolymphatic fluid in the cochlea. 3. Various factors such as trauma, infection, allergy, autoimmune, hormonal, vascular and viral have been implicated as possible causes of this dilation. 4. The signs and symptoms of Meniere's disease are believed to be caused by increased volume of endolymphatic fluid in the cochlea. 5. The main symptom of Meniere's Disease is an abnormal sensation of hearing, often referred to as "sea-shell" or "roaring" in the affected ear. 6. It is usually associated with tinnitus, hearing loss and sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear. 7. Hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy is one of the accepted treatments for Meniere's disease. 8. The exact mechanism of action of HBO in Meniere's disease is still not known. 9. It is postulated that HBO will cause vasoconstriction of the vascular system of the inner ear, thereby reducing the volume of endolymphatic fluid and possibly reversing the symptoms associated with Meniere's disease. 10. HBO therapy is usually administered as a monotherapy, in a treatment chamber where the patient breathes 100% oxygen at a pressure of 2.5 atmospheres for periods of 90 minutes each session. 11. The typical treatment protocol is 30 sessions, two sessions per day, three days per week for a total of six weeks. 12. HBO therapy has been shown to be effective in controlling the vertigo associated with Meniere's disease. 13. The evidence, however, for the benefit of HBO therapy in hearing loss and tinnitus associated with Meniere's disease is still limited.

The speech processor changes the code to a pattern of electrical impulses, which is sent to the transmitting coil. The transmitting coil sends the impulses through the skin to the implanted electrode array. The array sends the impulses to different parts of the cochlea, which then sends the impulses to the brain, where they are converted back to sound. 2. The compament above the septum is called the tunica vaginalis testis, and the compament below the septum is called the tunica albuginea testis. The tunica vaginalis testis surrounds the parenchyma of the testis, which consists of two major regions: the tubules and the interstitial tissue. The tubules of the testis are composed of the seminiferous tubules and the straight tubules. Seminiferous tubules. The straight tubules are continuous with the seminiferous tubules and are the sites of sperm transpo and maturation. 3. Male accessory organs. The seminal vesicles are two lobulated structures that lie inferior to the ampullae of the ductus deferens and lateral to the bladder. Each vesicle is composed of numerous tubules that terminate in a single excretory duct, which joins the ductus deferens to form the ejaculatory duct. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. The male reproductive system is made up of the male genitals and other organs that produce and transport sperm and male sex hormones. 2. The male genitals include the penis, testicles (or testes), and other structures such as the prostate, seminal vesicles, and the bulbourethral glands. 3. The penis is a cylindrical organ that contains spongy tissue and channels for urine and semen. It is covered by a layer of skin. The tip of the penis is called the glans. 4. The testicles are located in a pouch of skin behind the penis. The testicles produce and store sperm and male sex hormones. 5. The seminal vesicles (or vesiculae seminales) are two small glands located near the bladder that produce most of the fluid that makes up semen. 6. The prostate gland is located just below the bladder and in front of the rectum. It produces fluid that makes up part of the seminal fluid. 7. The bulbourethral glands (or Cowper's glands) are located in the pelvis near the base of the penis. They produce fluid that makes up part of the seminal fluid. 8. The male reproductive system produces and transports sperm and male sex hormones. 9. Sperm are produced in the testes and then stored in the epididymis until they are released through the penis during ejaculation. 10. The male sex hormone testosterone is produced by the testes and is also found in the circulating blood. Testosterone controls the development of the male reproductive organs and the secondary sex characteristics, such as the growth of body hair and the development of the musculature. It also has some effect on the metabolic rate and the production of red blood cells.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) The Mediterranean Diet: This diet is based on the traditional dietary patterns of the countries surrounding the Mediterranean Sea. This diet is based on whole, unprocessed foods such as fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole-grain bread and cereals. Olive oil is the primary source of fat, and fish are consumed frequently. Red meat is consumed rarely. Moderate amounts of alcohol are consumed. This diet has been associated with decreased risk of heart disease and certain cancers. It is designed for long-term adherence and is considered a safe and effective method for weight loss as well as disease prevention. 2) The DASH Diet: This diet is designed to be low in sodium and high in fiber. It emphasizes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy products. It is designed to lower blood pressure and reduce the risk of heart disease and some cancers. This diet is a good choice for individuals with high blood pressure or a family history of high blood pressure or heart disease. 3) Vegetarian Diet: This diet emphasizes plant-based foods such as vegetables, fruits, whole grains, legumes, and nuts. Some vegetarians do not eat dairy products or eggs. While vegetarian diets have been shown to be effective for weight loss and disease prevention, they may be difficult to follow for some individuals. 4) Low-Carbohydrate Diet: This type of diet emphasizes foods with a low carbohydrate content. The two most popular forms of this diet are the Atkins Diet and the Zone Diet. This diet is designed for rapid weight loss. However, long-term studies have shown that this diet is no more effective for weight loss and weight maintenance than other types of diets. In addition, this type of diet has been associated with an increased risk of heart disease and certain cancers. It is not considered a safe and effective method for weight loss and disease prevention.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Crossed eye (strabismus) is an eye alignment disorder in which the eyes are not properly aligned. 2. The brain then sends a message to the eye muscles to move the eye in the correct direction, but the eye muscle does not move the eye properly because it is not working correctly. 4. This causes one eye to look straight while the other eye looks in a different direction. 5. Crossed eye is most often found in infants and young children. It is usually not a problem in adults because the brain begins to ignore the image from one eye. 6. In children, crossed eye can cause problems because the brain is still learning to see. 7. Crossed eye can also cause problems with depth perception and can affect a child's ability to see in three dimensions. 8. There are several types of crossed eye. The most common types are esotropia (the eye turns inward), exotropia (the eye turns outward), and hyperopia (the eye is too far away from the nose). 9. Crossed eye may be caused by cranial nerve problems, eye muscle problems, eye injury, or eye tumors. 10. Treatment depends on the cause and the type of crossed eye. Skin grafts are generally considered more appropriate for older adults who may have medical problems that make them poor candidates for reconstructive surgery.5. Skin grafts may also be used for patients with limited life expectancy, since the cosmetic results are often less important to them.6. Skin grafts are also more appropriate for patients who are less likely to be compliant with the postoperative wound care required for flap procedures.7. Skin grafts are generally considered appropriate when the recipient bed has adequate vascular supply and when there is adequate mobility of the wound edges to allow for closure of the donor site.8. Skin grafts are generally less appropriate when the wound bed is not stable (e.g., due to infection or draining wound) or when there is extensive tissue loss or poor circulation to the recipient area.9. Skin grafts may be less appropriate for patients with poor overall circulatory status or immunocompromised patients due to the risk of graft failure.

Your doctor may recommend an operation to correct ear deformities or other problems in the outer or middle ear. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1.1.1. Treatment of Hyperkalemia: The treatment of hyperkalemia should be approached in a stepwise manner. Initially, antagonism of the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia can be attempted with the administration of calcium gluconate. Calcium raises the action potential threshold and reduces the excitability of cardiac myocytes in the presence of hyperkalemia. The effect is relatively rapid, but generally dissipates within minutes. The effect can be sustained by the administration of a calcium-chelating agent, such as calcium resonium or calcium-sodium edetate. These agents will rapidly lower serum calcium levels, thus diminishing the effects of the calcium gluconate. 1.1.2. Potassium Removal: The removal of potassium can be accomplished by the use of potassium-removing agents. The two most commonly used agents are sodium polystyrene sulfonate (SPS) and loop diuretics. SPS exchanges Na+ for K+ in the gastrointestinal tract and increases the fecal excretion of K+. Loop diuretics induce the secretion of K+ into the urine by augmenting the flow of salt across the renal tubule. 1.1.3. Potassium Replacement: After the acute hyperkalemic crisis has been resolved, the patient may require potassium replacement. Generally, potassium can be administered when the serum potassium level is below 3.0 meq/L. When it is above 3.0 meq/L, dextrose-containing intravenous fluids should be administered to lower the serum potassium level. Potassium replacement can be accomplished by the administration of potassium chloride, potassium bicarbonate, or potassium phosphate. 1.1.4. Potassium-Sparing Agents: Patients with a significant defect in renal potassium excretion may require the use of a potassium-sparing diuretic. The two potassium-sparing diuretics are amiloride and triamterene. These agents are generally used in conjunction with other di

OI is a genetic disorder that affects the development of bones. People with OI have bones that are very fragile and break easily. People with OI usually have white spots in their skin and may have blue sclerae (the whites of their eyes are blue). 3. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Asthma is a long-term disease that has no cure. However, with proper treatment and care, most people with asthma are able to achieve good health.2. It is possible to reduce the number and severity of asthma attacks, decrease the need for emergency room visits and reduce the need for medication.3. The goals of asthma treatment include: Preventing chronic and troublesome symptoms, such as coughing and shortness of breath; Reducing your need for reliever medication; Reducing your exposure to environmental factors that may trigger asthma symptoms or attacks; and Helping you to maintain good lung function.4. To control asthma, your doctor may recommend two kinds of medication: Reliever medication - to be taken at the first sign of an asthma attack, and Preventer medication - to reduce inflammation and help control asthma symptoms.5. Asthma medicines come in many forms, including inhalers, tablets, and liquids.6. Asthma medicines may be taken on a regular basis to help control asthma. They may be taken by mouth or inhaled.7. The choice of medicine depends on your symptoms, your medical history, and your respiratory function test results.8. Asthma medicines may have different effects on different people. It is important to learn how your medicines work and how to take them properly.9. If you need to use your reliever medication more than twice a week, or if you need to use your preventer medication more than twice a month, your asthma is not under good control. You should talk to your doctor about your symptoms and possibly change your treatment.10. If you have asthma, your doctor may also want you to have a flu vaccination every year, as well as a pneumococcal vaccination every five to six years.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1:
2003;120(10):1528-32. The opinions of Dutch GPs and specialists regarding the curability of asthma. van den Berg-Emmersmann E, van der Molen T, Nijkamp A, Rabe K. Abstract BACKGROUND: Asthma is an increasing problem in the Netherlands and in other Western countries. Although much is known about the pathophysiology of asthma, the curability of asthma is still controversial. OBJECTIVE: To explore Dutch GPs' and specialists' beliefs regarding the curability of asthma. DESIGN: Cross-sectional survey. METHOD: A questionnaire was sent to 1000 GPs and 500 specialists working in the Dutch health care system, asking for their opinions regarding the curability of asthma and the reasons underlying their opinions. RESULTS: A total of 428 GPs (43%) and 228 specialists (45%) responded. Most GPs (68%) and specialists (81%) thought that asthma was not curable. The most frequently mentioned reason by GPs was that asthma had a complex pathophysiology, whereas specialists mainly mentioned the occurrence of exacerbations as an indication of the uncurability of asthma. Most GPs (69%) and specialists (67%) mentioned no treatment as the most important factor for uncurability. CONCLUSION:Although most GPs and specialists thought that asthma was not curable, no uniform opinion existed regarding the reasons for this uncurability. These beliefs may influence the way GPs and specialists treat their patients with asthma.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Whipple's disease (WD) is a rare systemic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei.  The disease is characterized by infiltration of small intestinal mucosa by macrophages that contain PAS-positive granules (positive with periodic acid-Schiff stain).  Untreated WD results in progressive malabsorption and, eventually, death from starvation or the development of CNS symptoms.  The disease may present with CNS symptoms in the absence of GI symptoms.  The mean time to death is 7 to 10 years after the onset of GI symptoms.  The clinical course of the disease is more rapid in patients who present at a younger age and in those who present with CNS symptoms.  A rare form of WD, known as CNS-predominant disease, is characterized by the development of neurologic symptoms in the absence of GI symptoms.  The disease may also present as a cardiac valvular or large vessel vasculitis.  Untreated WD leads to progressive malabsorption and, eventually, death from starvation or the development of CNS symptoms.  The disease may present with CNS symptoms in the absence of GI symptoms.  The clinical course of the disease is more rapid in patients who present at a younger age and in those who present with CNS symptoms.  A rare form of WD, known as CNS-predominant disease, is characterized by the development of neurologic symptoms in the absence of GI symptoms.  The disease may also present as a cardiac valvular or large vessel vasculitis.

In infants, the most common symptom is failure to thrive (not gaining weight and growing normally). 9. The symptoms of Whipple disease may come and go. 10. People with this condition are diagnosed with other diseases, such as arthritis, before the diagnosis of Whipple disease is made. 11. The disease is most often diagnosed in people between the ages of 30 and 50. Men are affected more often than women. 12. There is no specific test for Whipple disease. The diagnosis is usually made by a combination of the patient's symptoms, physical exam, blood tests, and x-rays or other imaging tests. 13. In patients with intestinal symptoms, a tissue sample from inside the small intestine may be taken to look for signs of Whipple disease. This test is called a small intestinal biopsy. 14. There is no specific treatment for Whipple disease. Antibiotics are used to treat the disease. 15. Without treatment, the disease can cause severe damage to the intestines, heart, and brain. 16. The outcome of the disease varies. Some patients get better after treatment. Others may continue to have symptoms for many years. Still others may develop life-threatening complications, such as heart or lung disease.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Type 1 diabetes is a condition in which your body does not produce insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps glucose get into your cells to give them energy. Without insulin, too much glucose stays in your blood. Over time, high blood glucose can lead to serious problems with your heart, eyes, kidneys, nerves, and gums and teeth. 2. Your immune system is your defense against disease. It attacks something that seems foreign, like bacteria or viruses. In people with type 1 diabetes, the immune system attacks and destroys the insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas. This is called autoimmune destruction. No one knows what starts the attack. It may be a virus or a diet high in animal fats and proteins. 3. Another theory is that the immune attack is triggered by a virus or other infection. Researchers are studying this theory. They have found evidence of viruses in the pancreas of people with type 1 diabetes. 4. Type 1 diabetes develops most often in children and young adults. Only 5 to 10 percent of people with type 1 diabetes are over age 30. It is most common in people who have family members with type 1 diabetes. It is less common in people who have family members with type 2 diabetes. 5. Type 1 diabetes is less common in African Americans than in whites.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Two major types of diabetes are type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes. Type 1 diabetes usually develops in childhood or early adulthood. With type 1 diabetes, the body does not produce insulin.  Type 2 diabetes usually develops in middle-aged and older adults. With type 2 diabetes, the more common form of diabetes, the body does not produce enough insulin or cannot use it properly. With both types of diabetes, glucose levels in the blood become very high and this causes damage to the blood vessels and nerves. High blood glucose levels can also cause loss of weight and tiredness.  The cause of diabetes depends on the type of diabetes. With type 1 diabetes, researchers think that the body's immune system attacks the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. The exact cause of this attack is not known. With type 2 diabetes, although the exact cause is also not known, researchers think that obesity and lack of exercise may play a part. Obesity may cause the body to become resistant to insulin, so that more insulin is needed. Lack of exercise may cause the muscle and liver cells to become resistant to insulin.  Other risk factors for type 2 diabetes include having a family history of diabetes, having been diagnosed with gestational diabetes, and having impaired glucose metabolism. Gestational diabetes is diabetes that occurs during pregnancy and goes away after delivery. Impaired glucose metabolism is a condition in which blood glucose levels are between normal and diabetic levels. People with impaired glucose metabolism are at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 3 main factors are autoimmunity, genetic susceptibility, and beta cell dysfunction.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Diabetes is a chronic disease that results from a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors.  The major susceptibility gene for type 1 diabetes is located in the HLA region on chromosome 6. The most strongly associated alleles are the HLA DR3 and/or DR4 haplotypes. However, most individuals with these haplotypes do not develop diabetes. Additional genetic loci that may contribute to the development of type 1 diabetes include the variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) in the insulin gene, and the polymorphisms for the IL-10 and IL-1 receptors.  Many environmental factors have also been implicated as risk factors for the development of type 1 diabetes, including viral infections, nutritional factors, and toxins.  Several viruses including rubella, mumps, coxsackie, influenza, and paramyxovirus have been implicated as potential triggers for the development of type 1 diabetes.  Nutritional factors including breastfeeding and the intake of cows' milk have also been implicated as potential triggers.  In addition, several toxins including nitrosamines, 2-methoxyethyl alcohol, and various forms of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) have also been implicated as potential triggers.  The exact mechanism by which any of these factors might trigger the development of type 1 diabetes is unknown.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that can damage the optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness in the United States. It generally happens when the fluid pressure inside your eyes slowly rises, damaging your optic nerve. Often there are no symptoms at first. Without treatment, people with glaucoma will slowly lose their peripheral, or side vision. They seem to be looking through a tunnel. Over time, straight-ahead vision may decrease until no vision remains.  A comprehensive eye exam can tell if you have glaucoma. This exam includes testing your visual acuity (vision sharpness), checking your pupils, and measuring the pressure in your eyes.  Treatment for glaucoma is tailored to each patient. It may include prescription eyedrops, glaucoma surgery, or other eye medicines. The goal of treatment is to reduce pressure in the eye to prevent damage to the optic nerve. NIH: National Eye Institute
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Glaucoma is a group of diseases that cause damage to the optic nerve and vision loss. 2. It is a leading cause of blindness in the United States. 3. The most common type of glaucoma is open-angle glaucoma. It is chronic and slowly progressive. 4. Vision loss usually occurs gradually and painlessly. 5. The angle between the iris and cornea is where fluid leaves the eye. When the angle is blocked, fluid can't leave the eye. This causes the pressure inside the eye to increase. 6. Elevated pressure inside the eye can damage the optic nerve and cause vision loss. 7. Open-angle glaucoma is treated with eyedrops, pills, or laser surgery. 8. To keep eye pressure at a normal level, you may need to use eyedrops every day for the rest of your life. 9. Other types of glaucoma are acute (angle-closure) glaucoma and secondary glaucoma.

However, if the condition is left untreated long enough, vision loss can occur. 4. There are several different types of glaucoma. One type is acute angle-closure glaucoma. This is a different kind of glaucoma than open-angle glaucoma. It is more common in people who are farsighted and occurs less often. 5. Other types of glaucoma include secondary glaucoma and congenital glaucoma. Secondary glaucoma is caused by some other eye problem, such as diabetes, high blood pressure, or tumors. Congenital glaucoma is a rare type of glaucoma. It is present at birth.

Risk Factors for Glaucoma  - Age. The risk of chronic glaucoma increases after age 40.  - Family history. People with a family history of glaucoma are at higher risk.  - Race. African Americans have a higher risk of glaucoma than other races.  - Glaucoma tends to run in families.  - High eye pressure. The higher the eye pressure, the greater the risk.  - Older age. The risk increases with age.  - Diabetes. Diabetes may increase the risk of glaucoma.  - A history of eye injuries.  - Certain medicines. These include corticosteroids (for example, prednisone), a drug called beta blockers, and some anti-glaucoma medicines.  - Other medical problems. These include heart disease, high blood pressure, and chronic diarrhea.  - Nearsightedness (myopia).  - Frequent changes in the shape or size of the eye (axial myopia).  - Eye trauma.  - Cataracts.  4. The Eye of the Glaucoma: The optic nerve is the structure at the back of the eye that carries visual information to the brain. In glaucoma, the optic nerve is gradually damaged. 5. Symptoms  - Early glaucoma has no symptoms. That's why glaucoma is such a dangerous disease—the vision loss is painless and gradual, so many people don't know they have it until the disease has caused significant vision loss.   - As the disease progresses, there may be:  - Vision loss.  - Hazy

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The most common cause of pain in the ball and socket joint is subluxation of the hip. This is a partial dislocation of the hip joint. This fracture is usually caused by a fall on the side of the hip. 3. Another common cause of subluxation of the hip is a disease called avascular necrosis of the femoral head. This disease is caused by a disruption of the blood supply to the femoral head. 4. Other causes of subluxation of the hip include bone diseases such as osteoporosis, rickets, and osteomalacia. 5. There are also some congenital conditions of the hip that can cause subluxation of the hip. 6. The diagnosis of subluxation of the hip is made by taking an x-ray of the pelvis. 7. Treatment of subluxation of the hip depends upon the cause. If the subluxation is caused by a fracture, it is usually treated with a hip replacement. If the subluxation is caused by avascular necrosis, it is usually treated with core decompression and or bone grafting. If the subluxation is caused by one of the other conditions mentioned above, it is usually treated with core decompression. 8. In any case, you should see your doctor for an evaluation.

Metatropic dysplasia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and has an onset in infancy. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1.1 creatinine is normal. It doesn't mean that you don't have any kidney problems. Creatinine level may be normal in early stages of kidney diseases.  Stones won't affect the creatinine result.  Creatinine is a waste product from our muscles. It is removed from the body by our kidneys.  If the kidneys are working well, then creatinine is removed from the body and the blood levels are low.  If the kidneys are not working well, then creatinine builds up in the blood and the levels go up.  You can have a kidney stone and still have normal creatinine levels, but if the stone is blocking your kidney, then the creatinine will go up.  So, it doesn't mean you don't have kidney problems if your creatinine is normal.  You should be checked for protein in your urine, and you should have an ultrasound to see if the stone is blocking your kidney.

A stone in the kidney would not cause a sudden increase in creatinine, but it would cause a slow and gradual increase. If you have a stone, and you have pain, nausea and vomiting, you should go to the hospital. If you don't have pain, you can wait and see a nephrologist.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1.1 is not that bad, so your stone is not affecting your kidney too much. Creatinine is a waste product that comes from the normal wear and tear of muscle tissue. PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. The death of a loved one can trigger a grief response that can last for a year or more. The grief can be intense, but it usually diminishes over time. 2. Grief can also be affected by other factors, such as the type of death (expected vs. unexpected), the cause of death (natural vs. accident), and the relationship to the person who died. 3. Grieving doesn't always follow a predictable course. It can be affected by many things, such as your personality, your coping style, your ability to make decisions and your religious and spiritual beliefs. 4. You may find yourself thinking about your loved one and thinking about what you would say if he or she were alive. You might have emotional outbursts, or find yourself acting impulsively. 5. Some people find that they have trouble sleeping, or they sleep too much. You might find yourself not wanting to get out of bed in the morning. 6. You might also find that you don't want to eat or that you eat too much. 7. You might have physical symptoms, such as dry mouth, or heaviness in your arms or legs. 8. Some people find that they can't concentrate or make decisions the way they used to. 9. You might feel very angry or very guilty, even about things that aren't really related to the death. 10. Grieving can be affected by other things, such as major life events, illnesses, and anniversaries. For example, when you hear a song that your mother used to like, you might feel sad. 11. Grief can be affected by how you cope. For example, if you try to avoid talking about the person who died, you might not feel better. Instead, you might continue to feel sad and as if you can't get over the death. 12. Some people have complicated grief. This means that the normal grief you feel after a loved one dies gets in the way of your everyday life. For example, you might not be able to function at work or you might isolate yourself from other people. 13. If your grief is getting in the way of your everyday life, talk to your doctor. He or she can help you figure out what to do.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: In the general population, infertility is defined as the failure to conceive after one year of unprotected intercourse. In males, infertility is generally assumed after three months of failed intercourse. Female infertility is more complex, however, and can be caused by a number of factors including hormonal imbalances, blocked fallopian tubes, problems with ovulation, and uterine abnormalities. Women with ovarian failure may experience infertility because of a lack of eggs to become fertilized. Ovarian failure can result from chemotherapy or radiation treatment, autoimmune disease, or genetic abnormalities. Cancer treatment, especially with chemotherapy drugs, can affect fertility in both sexes, often resulting in temporary infertility. Radiation therapy to the pelvis may also damage ovarian and testicular function.  Research suggests that women who have their ovaries removed before the age of 40 are at high risk for infertility. For those under age 40, the risk of infertility after unilateral oophorectomy is 15 percent, compared to 30 percent for those who have both ovaries removed. In addition, the risk of infertility increases with age at the time of oophorectomy. For example, the risk of infertility is about 20 percent for women who have their ovaries removed before age 30, compared to 40 percent for women who have the procedure performed after age 40.  In addition, women who have had a hysterectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the uterus, are at increased risk for infertility. The risk depends on the woman's age at the time of surgery and the type of hysterectomy performed. For example, the risk of infertility is about 25 percent for women who have a hysterectomy before age 35, compared to about 40 percent for women who have the procedure performed after age 35.  There are many ways to treat infertility, including in vitro fertilization, intrauterine insemination, ovulation induction, and intracytoplasmic sperm injection.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The loss of sensation and weakness in the leg is likely due to a condition called peripheral neuropathy. 2. Peripheral neuropathy is a condition caused by damage to the peripheral nervous system [the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord]. 3. Damage to these nerves can cause numbness, tingling, pain, and weakness in the legs, hands, and feet. 4. Causes of peripheral neuropathy include:  - Diabetes  - Long-term alcohol abuse  - Exposure to toxic substances or heavy metals  - Certain viral diseases such as shingles or hepatitis  - Autoimmune diseases such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis  - Malnutrition or vitamin deficiencies  - Kidney failure  - Excess blood sugar or abnormal proteins in the blood  - Certain medications 5. In some cases, no treatment is needed. However, if the cause of the neuropathy can be determined and treated, the symptoms may go away. 6. Treatment will depend on the cause of the neuropathy. If the cause cannot be determined, treatment will be aimed at relieving symptoms. 7. Medications that may be used include:  - Pain relievers such as acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)  - Pregabalin (Lyrica), gabapentin (Neurontin), or amitriptyline  - Tricyclic antidepressants such as nortriptyline  - Anticonvulsant medications such as carbamazepine (Tegretol), phenytoin (Dilantin), or gabapentin  - Ultrasound or physical therapy 8. You should talk to your doctor about the best treatment for you.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Autosomal recessive primary microcephaly (MCPH) is a rare genetic disorder of the brain that results in impaired brain development. Individuals with MCPH have a small head (microcephaly) and a reduced number of cells in the brain (microencephaly). Infants with MCPH typically have normal growth and weight at birth, but they fail to grow at a normal rate during the first year of life. They may have developmental delays, including delayed motor milestones such as sitting up, crawling, and walking. Children with MCPH have a range of additional features including seizures, muscle weakness, speech delay, hearing and vision problems, and intellectual disability. The features of MCPH vary among affected individuals, depending on the severity of the disorder. Some individuals with MCPH have more severe intellectual disability and require lifelong support.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Autosomal Recessive Primary Microcephaly (MCPH) is a rare genetic condition that affects the brain and results in significant growth delays of the head and brain. 2. MCPH is caused by mutations in the MCPH1, WDR62, CDKN1B, CENPJ, and CEP152 genes. 3. People with MCPH have severely reduced head growth in the womb and as newborns. They also have a small head (microcephaly) and developmental delay. 4. Children with MCPH develop normally for the first few years of life. Then their development slows and they develop problems with movement and communication. 5. There is no cure for MCPH, and treatment is focused on the symptoms. 6. People with MCPH typically have a normal lifespan.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: No
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Autosomal Recessive Primary Microcephaly: This is a rare primary microcephaly syndrome with characteristics of severe MR (IQ usually less than 40), epilepsy, and characteristic facial features (including a long, narrow head, down-slanting palpebral fissures, and a small chin). The disease is caused by mutations in the MCPH1, WDR62, or PHC1 genes. 2. Autosomal Recessive Primary Microcephaly: This is another rare primary microcephaly syndrome with characteristics of severe MR (IQ usually less than 40), epilepsy, and characteristic facial features (including a long, narrow head, down-slanting palpebral fissures, and a small chin). The disease is caused by mutations in the PHC1 or PHC2 genes.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: My answer is that you should ask your doctor to refer you to a geneticist or a genetic counselor. PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. The first description of autosomal recessive primary microcephaly (MCPH) was in 1960 by G. E. Bergsma and A. M. Dempsey. 2. It was first described in a Brazilian family by Harding and colleagues in 1991. 3. The term MCPH has been used to describe patients with normal brain weight and head circumference at birth who develop microcephaly in the first 2 years of life. 4. Patients present with mild intellectual disability and characteristic facial features such as a long, narrow head, hypertelorism, and a small jaw. 5. Seizures and abnormalities of vision, hearing, or the cardiac or skeletal systems are common. 6. The disease has been mapped to chromosome 19q13 in 1998 and subsequently to mutations in the MCPH1 gene. 7. Mutations in the MCPH1 gene have also been found in patients with lissencephaly type 2.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Diagnosis: VDRL test is a nonspecific test for syphilis. It detects the presence of antibodies that are produced by a person who has been infected with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis. 2. Precaution: If the test is positive, you will need additional tests to determine if you still have syphilis. You will also need to be treated if you still have syphilis.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Get Tested for Syphilis 2. Get Tested for HIV 3. Get a Complete Physical Exam 4. Get Counseling 5. Get Medical Treatment 6. Get Follow-Up Tests
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease. So, patient with positive vdrl should avoid sexual contact with others till treatment is complete. 2. Patient should also avoid sharing needles with others if they are drug addicts. 3. Patient should be advised to take care of their personal items like tooth brush, razors etc. which should not be shared with others. 4. Patient should be advised to take precautions during sexual intercourse. Condom should be used by both the partners.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Patients with a reactive VDRL test should be given a thorough clinical examination to determine whether they have any signs or symptoms of syphilis. 2. Patients with a reactive VDRL test who have no signs or symptoms should undergo a confirmatory test for syphilis, such as: - RPR - FTA-ABS - TPHA - TPPA 3. Patients with a positive confirmatory test should be managed according to the stage of syphilis. 4. Patients with a reactive VDRL test who have no signs or symptoms should be given the same treatment as patients with a positive confirmatory test if the following apply: - the patient is a woman in her first trimester of pregnancy - the patient has HIV infection - the patient has a history of treatment for syphilis during the past 12 months. 5. Patients with a reactive VDRL test who have no signs or symptoms and who do not meet the criteria for treatment should be retested at 3 month intervals for 1 year. If the test remains reactive at 1 year, the patient should be managed as if they have latent syphilis.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Patients who have tested positive for syphilis by a nontreponemal serologic test (RPR or VDRL) should be considered for treatment unless the test can be confirmed as a false positive.2. Patients with a positive confirmatory treponemal test (FTA-ABS or TPHA) do not need to be retested with a nontreponemal serologic test unless the confirmatory treponemal test was performed using a non-standardized method (e.g., in-house test).3. Patients with a positive nontreponemal serologic test should be asked if they have had a previous positive serologic test for syphilis. If the patient has a past positive serologic test for syphilis and the current nontreponemal serologic test is positive, the patient should be treated for syphilis.4. Patients with a positive nontreponemal serologic test who are not HIV-infected and who have not previously been treated for syphilis should be considered for treatment with penicillin. Patients allergic to penicillin should be treated with a macrolide.5. Patients with a positive nontreponemal serologic test who are HIV-infected should be evaluated for the presence of a treponemal infection. If the evaluation is negative, the patient should be treated for syphilis. Patients who have a history of penicillin allergy should be desensitized and treated with penicillin. Patients who have a positive confirmatory treponemal test may be treated with penicillin or a macrolide if compliance cannot be assured.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. The VDRL test is a nonspecific test for syphilis, and a positive result means that the patient has or had syphilis at some time. 2. A positive VDRL test needs to be confirmed with a specific test such as the FTA-ABS test, which is more specific for syphilis. 3. The VDRL test will remain positive for years after the initial treatment for syphilis, so it is not a good way to check whether the patient's syphilis has been cured. 4. Patients with a positive VDRL test should be asked whether they have ever had syphilis or had treatment for syphilis in the past. 5. Patients with a positive VDRL test should be told that they need to be retested with the FTA-ABS test to confirm that they have syphilis. 6. Patients with a positive VDRL test who are not reactive on the FTA-ABS test should be told that they may have had syphilis in the past but do not currently have syphilis.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. The best way to check for MRSA elimination is to take swabs from the nose and/or throat and send them to the laboratory for testing.2. If the swabs are negative for MRSA, it is likely that you are clear of MRSA.3. It is important to remember that even if you have no symptoms, you may still be carrying MRSA in your nose or throat and could still infect others.4. If you do have symptoms, you may need a course of antibiotics to clear the infection.5. If you are being treated with antibiotics for a different infection, make sure you complete the full course of antibiotics, even if your symptoms disappear.6. If you are treated for MRSA infection, you may need to take swabs when you are discharged from hospital to make sure you are clear of MRSA.7. If you are still carrying MRSA, you may need further treatment or a decolonisation regimen.8. If you are still carrying MRSA and you keep getting reinfected, you may need a decolonisation regimen.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The gold standard test is a bacterial culture of nasal secretions, wound exudates, blood, and other appropriate specimens.2. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing can be used to detect the mecA gene, which is specific for MRSA.3. The latex agglutination test can also be used to detect the PNAG (Penicillin-binding Protein-2a) antigen, which is expressed by most, but not all, MRSA isolates.4. Enzyme immunoassays are being developed for use in the clinical microbiology laboratory for the rapid detection of MRSA.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Yes, there is a test to check for MRSA clearance. It is called a "culture test". 2. If MRSA grows, you are a "carrier". 5. If no MRSA grows, you are "cured".

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1) If the papilloma is very small, your doctor may decide to wait and watch. This means that he or she will do regular physical exams and Pap smears to make sure the papilloma is not growing or changing. 2) If the papilloma is large, your doctor may recommend a loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP). This is a simple surgery that can usually be done in a doctor's office. A small wire loop is heated by a low-voltage electrical current. The loop is used to remove the abnormal tissue. LEEP is a much less invasive procedure than traditional surgery. You will have less bleeding and less pain. You will also need fewer days to recover.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1) The first thing to do is to determine the cause of the balance disorder.  A physical examination by a neurologist or a physician who specializes in balance disorders would be the first step.  The examination will determine whether the problem is in the brain or the inner ear or somewhere in between.  The doctor will also determine whether the problem is acute or chronic.  If the problem is acute, it could be something as simple as ear infection or as serious as a stroke.  If the problem is chronic, it could be something as common as benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) or Meniere's disease or as rare as a brain stem tumor.  Once the cause is determined, then the appropriate treatment can be initiated. 2) In the meantime, there are some things that can be done to help the patient cope with the balance disorder. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) Physical therapy - your father can visit a physical therapist who will assess his balance and gait. Based on the assessment, the therapist will provide your father with exercises to improve his balance and gait. 2) Medications - your father can try medications such as chlorthalidone, indapamide, alpha-blockers, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors and calcium channel blockers. These medications will help reduce the blood pressure and improve his balance. 3) Vestibular rehabilitation - your father can try this treatment option if he has a history of recurring vertigo. The therapist will teach him exercises to improve his balance and coordination. 4) Surgery - this treatment option is used in cases where the patient has severe vertigo or hearing loss. Surgery includes labyrinthectomy, vestibular nerve section and singular neurectomy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Your father should be evaluated by a neurologist to determine the cause of his balance disorder.  The neurologist may order imaging studies, nerve conduction studies, or blood work.  Balance disorders can be caused by anything that affects the inner ear, the cerebellum, or the brain.  Treatment depends on the underlying cause of the disorder.  Balance disorders that are caused by problems with the inner ear may be treated with medications that help to reduce dizziness or with surgery.  Balance disorders that are caused by problems with the cerebellum or the brain may be treated with medications, physical therapy, or surgery.
